div.p: 1. VI. Walk round Capitol Square. Sun rose 7:

My first visitor was Mr Briscoe, who came to solicit an appointment in behalf of his Son. The next was the Secretary of the Senate, who brought the confirmation of the nominations of the Directors of the Bank of the United States, and a few others— From Noon till 3. O’Clock, the New-Year’s Drawing-Room was held, and as numerously attended as on any former occasion— About two thirds of the Members of both Houses of Congress, and all the foreign Ministers now in the City were present. The scruples of the late Ministers from France and Russia seem to have been personal, and not sustained by their Governments— Baron Krudener, Mr Vaughan, and the Chevalier Huygens, with their families and Legations were all here— Also Mr Obregon, the Count de Menou, Baron Stackeberg, and Mr Rebello. All the Heads of Departments and their families, the subordinate Officers of Government, civil, military and naval; and many hundreds of private Citizens of this place and all the neighbouring regions— All the open rooms were crowded and overflowing.— The day was uncommonly fine, and the weather temperate— Mrs. B. O. Tayloe thanked me for the lines I had written in her Album, which was returned to her this Morning. At three O’Clock, I withdrew from the Room with Mr Rush to my writing Chamber, and signed the order for the release of Edward Thompson from prison, upon the back of the certificate of the two Physicians— Mr Rush read me a Letter from G. M’Duffie, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, asking for his more detailed Views, regarding the modifications of the Tariff, and alterations of duties upon Woollens, Hemp, Iron, fine Cottons, Teas and Wines. He had brought with him the second of W. H. Crawfords Letters to him written last Winter and Spring, and promised me copies of both— The Legislature of Georgia have nominated Crawford as a Candidate for the Office of Vice-President. The Legislature of the last year had already nominated General Jackson for the Presidency— Mr Everett, Mr and Mrs Frye, and T. J. Hellen dined with us. The family in the Evening after Mr Everett retired amused themselves at Cards. I returned to my Chamber, and under weariness insurmountable persevered in writing until near Midnight, when I closed the Diary of the departed year, with prayer for blessing on that now commenced— Especially for strength proportioned to its trials.
2. V:30— Rain. Walk round Capitol Square

Mr. Pleasonton came with a Letter from C. Grinnell enclosing sealed proposals for supplying Oil for all the Light Houses of the United States, with a request that he would open them only at a Meeting with the Secretary of the Treasury— The contracts are for five years; and for the last fifteen have been held by Winslow Lewis— Pleasonton was in some agitation, and said he considered it as an insult. I thought it little less myself, but told him it was probably not so intended. The imputation was that if he should open the proposals otherwise than in presence of the Secretary, Lewis would get a knowledge of them and underbid.— This implies a suspicion of Pleasonton’s integrity and was justly offensive to him. He seemed disposed to send back to Grinnell, who he said was a very respectable man, the sealed proposals with a passionate answer. I advised him simply to send them back with a notice, declining to comply with the condition, an unusual in the course of business; leaving Grinnell if he pleased to send his proposals directly to the Secretary of the Treasury— Mr Tharp came and I returned him his papers, together with my own decision upon his memorial, which I read to him.
Satterlee Clark was a paymaster in the Army—dismissed by order of Mr Monroe in August 1824—as a defaulter—under the 3d. Section of the Act of 31. January 1823. for having passed one Quarter without settling his Accounts— He was reported as a debtor to the amount of more than 15000 dollars, for which he has had three trials upon the suit of the Government—one Report of Referees, and two Verdicts of Juries in his favour. The verdict of the last Jury, the high respectability of whom is attested by the District Attorney Tillotson, is accompanied with a certificate that they find a balance of more than eleven thousand Dollars due to Clark— The failure to produce his accounts for Settlement in time, he attributes to a dangerous illness under which he was labouring— He now brought a certificate from the 3d. Auditor that his account had been credited, with the balance which had stood against him and also the Report of him as a defaulter, by the Paymaster General Towson in July 1824. the very day, Clark says, on which by the Law, he could make this Report—and the Letter from J. C. Calhoun written in August 1824. informing him that the President had directed that he should be dismissed. Clark said he did not consider this as a dismission, and that he claimed still to be in the service. He said that Mr. Oakley, and Mr Storrs, were preparing written opinions to that effect— I told him that if he should bring me those opinions, I would give them deliberate consideration; and with a disposition to do him all possible Justice—considering him as an injured man. He complained bitterly of the oppression that he had suffered— Said it had cost him more than four thousand dollars, and had held him up for four years before the Nation as a fraudulent defaulter and peculator of public monies— That it had driven him from absolute necessity into a party consisting of as great scoundrels as lived upon earth— These were his own words and they are entirely characteristic— He meant the Jackson party at New-York, with whom he has been acting to the full extent of his power— His principal motive for assuming the Jackson Livery was to secure a Jury favourably disposed to him, and he succeeded— His motive now for making such honourable mention of his associates is to propitiate me to this claim of his, to be recognized as yet in the public Service.— Mr Noland was a neighbour of Mr Monroe’s in Loudoun County—and was in 1824 appointed by him a Receiver of Public Monies in Arkansas. His term of four years will expire next Spring, and I had included his name in the list of renominations to be sent to the Senate— But he declines a reappointment, and returns to his old residence in Virginia— He told me that Mr Monroe had sold his Albemarle Slaves to pay a debt due to Mr Astor of New-York. The purchaser, who assumes the debt is Mr White the Delegate from Florida. He said Mr Monroe had yet another debt to the Bank at Richmond, contracted by his purchase of a House at Paris, when he was Minister to France in 1794. which house he afterwards sold at a sacrifice— I had always before heard that Mr Monroe had made a profit on the sale of that place, which was a confiscated emigrant Estate; purchased by him, and paid for in Assignats when they were at the lowest stage of depreciation. Mr Baker the Minister of the Presbyterian Church, called upon me, having just returned from his tour to Boston, where he says he has made a considerable collection for the Church— He thinks the debt of the Society to the Bank of the United States will be settled. There was a Spanish woman who came for charity coming from Philadelphia, with her husband and four children— She told me in French a long Story of their banishment from Spain for Politics, and then from South-America as Spaniards. Her own family, she said was Roland, and she was of French descent and Education— Mr Fendall came from the Department of State, with the Certificate of the two physicians concerning the health of Edward Thompson, and my order upon it for his discharge from prison— He asked upon what process he had been imprisoned. It was upon a Confession of Judgment. I asked Mr Fendall, to apply at the Treasury Department for Thompson’s Petition, and to annex it to the certificate upon which my order was drawn. Evening party at Mrs Freeman’s attended by the young Ladies and John.

General Van Rensselaer came to renew and urge the recommendation of John Duer as District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York— He mentioned several of the other Candidates who have been recommended, with strong objections against them— Of Edwards he said that his decisions as a judge had given so much dissatisfaction that there had been serious talk in the Legislature of removing him— Of Maxwell that he was odious to all parties, though he believed it was only because he had done his duty. Of David B. Ogden that he was obnoxious as a federalist, and Van Buren had told him that if he should be nominated he would use all his influence against him, in the Senate— Of Blunt that his forward officiousness and Vanity indisposed against him all the Bar— I told the General that Mr Tillotson the present Attorney had not declined a reappointment, and that as the expiration of his Commission was at hand, I had sent in his name to the Senate for re-appointment— The General thought he was utterly incompetent for the Office, and said he had been originally appointed only because he was a family connection of Mr Monroe. He spoke also of Moses Myers, the man whose nomination it was expected would be opposed in Senate, but which they have confirmed— Van Rensselaer said he believed their only objection against him was that he was an honest man— The first in that Collectorship for many years. The General has a very indifferent opinion of Silas Wright, the new Member from that District whom he considers as a tool of Van Buren, and who he says offered himself to him, as his Land Agent— He gave me as an example of the observation he had made about the Collectors at Oswegatchie, that during the late war one of his tenants applied to him for a loan of money for erecting an Establishment there for the Sale of Salt. “To smuggle into Canada,” said the General—“but how are you to escape the vigilance of the British authorities in the Province?” “Oh! there will be no difficulty with them”—[“]and how of the Collector?”— [“]Why, to tell you the truth, the Collector, is to be in partnership with me.”— The General, who is himself an honest and honourable man, testifies to no superfluity of political Virtue in the State of New-York— Governor Barbour brought papers, of applications from Indians, for permission to sell Lands reserved to them by Treaty— Mr Knight Senator from Rhode-Island, came to speak of the appointment of a Surveyor at the Port of North Kingston. He recommends Holloway, or Hammond—says the last is the best qualified— Dr Todsen came to solicit the appointment of Agent at the African Colony—which he says he should prefer to a renomination as assistant Surgeon in the Army— I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy. Mrs Hall came to solicit a Clerkship for her husband— She told me they had some months since removed to this City, for the purpose of procuring an Office— This is presumptive evidence of his unfitness for any— Mr Ellis of the Senate and Mr Forward of the House of Representatives of the Joint Committee of Enrolled Bills, brought me, for signature making partial Appropriations for the Support of Government during the year 1828 Providing for the pay and expenses of the two Houses of Congress; which I examined and signed. The first of the Session— The Evening was chiefly absorbed by successive visits from Mr Catlett of Alexandria, and Mr Everett— Catlett came to ask for a word from me to the judges of the Supreme Court to bestow the Office of Reporter of their decisions upon Richard Henry Lee— I told him it would give me pleasure to serve Mr Lee but that it was an appointment in which I could not with propriety interfere, and I had understood the Judges had already promised their suffrages to Mr Richard Peters junr. a very worthy friend of mine whom I had already assured of my wishes
for his success— He said there were only three of the judges who had promised their votes to Mr Peters, but that Mr Lee would certainly not wish me under these circumstances to intercede for him— Mr Everett spoke to me of a Resolution proposed by James Hamilton of South-Carolina, to the House of Representatives, for refunding all the monies paid upon Convictions under the Sedition Law—of the Constitutionality of which he asked my opinion— I said that not having been in the Country when that Law was enacted, I had never examined that question; but I had seen nothing unconstitutional in it— I had however no doubt that an Act of Congress declaring Unconstitutional an Act of a preceding Congress, Unconstitutional would itself be— He said that Mr. Barnard a new Member from New-York who boarded in the same house with him had told him he intended to reply to Hamilton upon this Resolution. With regard to the Vice-Presidency he said, it was settled that R. Rush would be nominated by the Harrisburg Convention— I received yesterday from Captain Basil Hall a Note enclosing Letters of introduction of himself written in March last, by Mrs Agnes Porter, and Mr Gallatin at London—two pamphlet publications by the Society for the diffusion of useful knowledge: which he had mentioned at the Institute dinner—and three small elegant Volumes, of his own Travels, published by the late Archibald Constable of Edinburg, in whose name, Captain Hall presents them— I this day answered his Note— There was a dancing party this Evening, at the Dutch Minister Huygens’s, attended by Mary, Abigail and John.
4. V. Round Capitol Square— Rain— Fog.

Having purchased a copy of Rees’s Cyclopaedia, the American Edition, I sent for Mr Este the Book binder, and gave him a direction for binding them— They were published in Numbers, somewhat confusedly: 87 Livraisons in the whole— Four of which are collections of Plates, Lettered A. B. C. and D. and the rest forming forty one Volumes, each in two Parts, and the 83d. part containing the Title pages to all the Volumes, the Preface, and Indexes of References to the Plates. Many of these were published also with each separate number, and the whole constitute Six Volumes. The whole work is therefore in 47— Mr Kane, a Senator from Illinois, came with Mr Stansbury whose object was to apply for a vacant Indian subagency for his Son— Mr Marvin, member of the House came to enquire concerning the Petition and papers of a man named Sheldon, imprisoned in the Western part of New-York for debt to the United States— Mr Sloane, Member from Ohio, called to recommend the final fixation of the Land Office at Tiffin— At one O’Clock Mr Clay came and introduced Baron Krudener, the Russian Minister, who delivered to me a Letter in Russian with a French Translation, from the Emperor Nicholas, announcing the birth, on the 9th (21st) of September of a Grand Duke named Constantine— On presenting the Letter the Baron said it had been despatched under a persuasion that the information of an Event so interesting as well to the domestic happiness of the Emperor, as to the stability of his Government. I answered by assuring him of the pleasure with which I received this communication— I added that the Government of the United States took a deep and cordial interest in every thing that affected the happiness of the Emperor, as well in his family, as in the affairs of his People, and that they judged no Event could more auspiciously contribute to this effect, than this accession to the Imperial family; none could therefore be more gratifying to them— He said he Should take the highest satisfaction in transmitting to his Government these Assurances— I then asked him how he found this climate agree with his health— He answered well; and said he would encourage himself in the expectation that it would so continue, notwithstanding the warnings that he had received—and they were many— He lamented that his hearing had so much suffered, as to deprive him of much satisfaction, and of the means of making himself so agreeable as he would desire— He comes with numerous testimonials, to the pleasantness of his character, and goodness of
his disposition— Mr George Tucker called to take leave—being about to return to his duty as a Professor at the University of Virginia. He spoke of two recent works, of which he acknowledged himself to be the other—one a novel called the Valley of the Shenandoah, which he said he had written in two Months; and the other a Voyage to the Moon— Of which his publisher P. Thompson, had by his direction sent me a Copy. But I had not known from whom it came; nor that he was the author of it. He said his object in the Valley of the Shenandoah was to paint the manners of that part of Virginia— That no notice of the Book had been taken in this Country, not so much as in a Newspaper— That he had therefore been the more gratified on learning that a translation of it had been published in France— Mr Garnsey, Member of the House of Representatives from New-York, came with the Revd. Eleazar Williams from Green-Bay, and Dr Jemison, both half breed and educated Indians of the Seneca tribe— Mr Williams brought a Letter from Mrs Boyd to Mrs. Adams; and a Letter of earnest recommendation to me, from Bishop Hobart— They came to repeat and renew the remonstrance by the Seneca Indians against the Treaty of the last Summer with the Winebago Indians, who they insist have now ceded to the United States, the same Lands which they had already Sold, to them. I referred them upon this, to the Secretary of War. Jemison brought me a Letter introductory from Mr Southard. He is a candidate for an appointment of Assistant Surgeon in the Navy— We had our weekly dinner party— Philip P. and Mrs Barbour and their two daughters, John Barney, David Barton, Thomas H. Blake, William L and Mrs Brent, John H. Bryan, William Creighton junr., Thomas W. Cobb, William Drayton, Henry W. Dwight, Jacob C. Isacks, Richard Keese, Joseph Lawrence, Isaac Leffler, John Maynard, Alfred H. Powell, Benjamin Ruggles, Horatio Seymour, Peleg SpragueJohn B. Sterigere, Henry W. and Mrs Storrs, Joseph M. and Mrs White and Miss Perry, Charles A. Wickliffe, Levi and Mrs Woodbury; with seven in the family 36 at table. I sent yesterday the Message N. 3. to Congress with the annual Report of the Commissioner of the Public Buildings; and this day Message N. 11 to the Senate, and Correspondence with the British Government concerning Light Houses in the Gulph of Mexico.
5. V. Round Capitol Square— Fog.

Mr Woodcock, a member of the House of Representatives from New York, came to solicit a Commission in the Army, for the Ex-Cadet Hughes— The same who was dismissed last Summer, by Sentence of a Court-Martial, and who was then so long and perseveringly pressed upon me then by himself, and by others; particularly by Judge Anderson— Mr Woodcock spoke of him as a youth poor and friendless, for whom he had obtained admission at the Academy, and referred to the very creditable manner in which he had passed through the course of Studies, and the final examination for the degree—having at the close of his term, ranked as the fifth in his Class I told him that this was true; but that the Reports upon his conduct were as unfavourable as those of his ability and proficiency were otherwise. That on his trial as well as on the occasion which produced it he had manifested a worse than contumacious Spirit— That the grant of a Commission to him now would have a pernicious effect, upon the discipline of the Academy. Events were too recent, and the danger to the Institution was too great to overlook what had passed— It was painful to me to refuse the applications in his favour, having a respect for his talents, and a strong feeling for his distressed situation; but a sense of duty to the Academy, and to the morals of all the young men now there, must be a paramount consideration— He asked, if he might write to him that good
conduct for a time would lead to a more favourable result— I said I could in candour authorize no such expectation in my time— What his prospects might be with others I could not foresee— I said I had not come to my determination before without consulting the Superintendant of the Academy, whose impressions were very decided against any relaxation from the decisions, excluding this young man from the army— Mr Woodcock spoke also upon one or two other subjects— Mr Bust was a stranger from the Western part of New-York— A casual visitor of curiosity— Mr Mallory, a member of the House from Vermont, and Mr Wing the Delegate from Michigan came together. Mr Wing said that the agreement for the exchange of Offices between Judge Witherell, and Secretary Woodbridge was now so far completed that he wished the nominations to be made without delay. I said I would send them in to the Senate on Monday.— Mr Wing wished that the Commissions might so be given that Mr Woodbridge should be chief Justice, but the Law recognizes no such distinction. I thought however his Commission might be first dated— He said he should hereafter recommend a person for the Office of Collector now held also by Mr Woodbridge— Mr Lowry the Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution asking information concerning the troubles on the Northeastern boundary— Mr Newton member of the House from Virginia came with Major Anderson of the Marine Corps, who has a claim for Brevet promotion. Mr Bryan, Member of the House from North-Carolina, introduced Mr Manning, just from the Administration Convention at Raleigh, and a Mr Merrill of Philadelphia. Mr J. Sergeant came with Mr Calhoun, a brother of him whom we knew in Russia— Mr Ruggles, a Senator, and Mr Stanberry a new Member of the House from Ohio came together— They spoke of an Act of the last Session of Congress, granting a Section of Land to the State, for aiding to make a Canal. There is some question upon the construction of the Act, of which Mr Ruggles stated that a written representation would be laid before me— Major Waldron came to take leave being about to return home to New-Hampshire— Mr Bell the Senator from that State, mentioned a claim of Coll. M’Neill of the Army, to Brevet promotion; for which I referred him to the Secretary of War— A young man by the name of Burnett, came to solicit an appointment as a Cadet at West-Point. Said his father had been a merchant in New-York, and had failed, in consequence of which he had himself been residing these three years in the interior of Pennsylvania— He had no recommendations, but appeared to be spirited and intelligent— I referred him to the War Department, where he said he had already entered his name as a Candidate. There was an Evening party at Governor Barbour’s, attended by our young Ladies, and by my Son John—
6. V:30. Sunday.

Heard this morning Mr Kent, from Genesis 1:26. “And God said, Let us make man, in our image, after our likeness.” The Sermon was a panegyric upon the human character, well composed and high wrought— The preacher considered all disparaging representations of human Nature, as incorrect both in fact and principle, and particularly disapproved the theory which denominates man a worm of the dust— But he did not look at the other side of the picture— Man as a physical being is a machine of animated matter, fearfully and wonderfully made—with wants which must be supplied to preserve his existence; and Passions which must be indulged for the preservation of his species— The power over the rest of Creation is in his hand: an instrument without which the intellect of Angels would not avail to give him dominion; but which God has given also to the Ape species, as if to shew how little it avails itself, without the intellect to direct and controul its use. By his material composition man belongs to earth— By the power of thought, man’s nature is Angelic, and in proportion as Heaven or Earth predominates in the person of each individual his character is glorious or debased. Man in his perfection is little lower than the Angels; but without the exercise, or with the perverted exercise of mind is
is little better than a worm of the dust— In his actual condition the Scriptures consider man as a fallen and degraded being— The sentence pronounced upon him was “dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return[”]— A degraded being he still remains by his Passions and his Vices— From these no mortal is wholly exempt; and Mr Kent’s picture of human nature seems to me overcharged with light as much as the Calvinistic Creed is overdarkened with shadows— Between the Services, Mr Joseph Blunt of New-York called to pay a visit. In the afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Keith of Alexandria read Prayers for the second Sunday after Christmas, omitting the Psalms of the day, and the Lesson from the Old Testament. It was the day of the Epiphany, but he did not read either the Lesson or the Collect assigned to it in the Prayer Book— He preached from Proverbs 14.32 “The wicked is driven away in his wickedness: but the righteous hath hope in his death.” A plain, well written and earnest discourse, contrasting the death bed Scenes of the wicked and of the righteous.— This passage is remarkable as one of those in the Old Testament, indicating the belief of a future state of retribution— I read in the Evening some of the Letters of Voltaire— Le Mondain, to which they refer, and the subsequent Poems in defence of that profligate Plaisanterie. I also read some of Montgomery’s Songs of Zion, which are versions of Psalms—not sufficiently vivid—
7. V— Sun rose 7:20.

Mr Silsbee came to introduce a Son of the late Commodore Preble, from Portland, who brought me also a Letter from Mr Wingate— He is going shortly to Europe— The Reverend Eleazar Williams. came with Beard, who he said had recently been made the first Chief of the Oneida Tribe— He spoke again in earnest complaint against the Treaty made last Summer by Governor Cass and T. L. M’Kenney with the Menominies at Green Bay. Williams said that if the Lands there purchased by the New-York Indians, should be left to them, the whole remaining body of the Six Nations amounting to five thousand would remove thither. He said too that the Indians at Green Bay were very desirous that Coll. Boyd, should be appointed the Agent to them, instead of Mr Prevost their present Agent, an old Man, whom they did not like— Mr Boyd was however very acceptable to them. Williams said also that he had baptised several of Mrs Boyd’s children. Mr Brent came to introduce Coll. Crane of Louisiana. Mr Cutts the second Comptroller, brought an Account presented for Settlement by Satterlee Clark, which was not among those brought forward by him on the late Trials— W Lee the 2d. Auditor had endorsed upon this Account that it could not be passed to his Credit, because he avowed that he had other claims, and they ought all to be brought forward, before this should be settled. But Cutts said he did not see that he could refuse a Settlement of this account upon the single ground that Clark had other claims— I concurred, in this opinion— He shewed me also an Account of Coll. Towson, the Pay Master General, who has received upwards of 1300 dollars, for Quarters and fuel—upon the Authority of the Army Regulations Section 1020. of 1. March 1825— Peter Hagner the 3d. Auditor has refused to allow this charge in the account of Coll. Cross who made the payment to Towson— Hagner considers this army Regulation, as contrary to Law, and therefore void—and has endorsed upon the account a reference to all the Acts of Congress relating to the Paymaster Generals Office— Cutts said he was of the same opinion, the Paymaster General being a Civil Officer with a fixed Salary—and therefore could
claim no allowance for Quarters and fuel— My own opinion was the same— Mr Clay called and spoke of a Note, he had received from Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires, complaining that a Buenos Ayrean Privateer had shipped five Seamen at New-York— He spoke also of the Convention which met at Harrisburg the 4th. of the manufacturing interest, and of the Vice-Presidency. The Count de Survilliers, the Prince de Musignano, and Captain Sari paid Morning visits, and also General Van Rensselaer with Mr Foote, and B. O. Tyler, with Mr M’Intire— Judge Thompson came afterwards, and Mr Blunt in the Evening— Judge Thompson mentioned that he had heard some observations, censuring the allowance of a Passage in the Delaware to the Prince of Musignano, and his family— Mr Blunt came to enquire if there was a prospect of his being nominated to the Senate as District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York— I told him I had nominated R. Tillotson, for re-appointment— He said he thought the nomination would meet with opposition in the Senate.— I sent this day Message N. 1. to the House of Representatives— Answer to a Call for Copies of the Correspondence with the British Government relating to the free navigation of the River St. Lawrence: and Message N. 12 to the Senate, with nominations— Signed a permission to Honore or the Cherokee Boy a Chief of the Wyandots to sell a quarter Section of Land to James Whitaker.
8. IV:30. Rain— Snow— Anniversary of the Battle of New-Orleans.

The weather has been several days sultry with fog and rain— I walked round the Capitol Square this morning, with rain which was followed by Snow. This continued nearly the whole day—but melted as it fell. Coll. Little, member of the House of Representatives from Baltimore County, came and introduced Mr Murray of that City— The Coll. asked me whether a Minister to England would be appointed this Winter— I told him probably not before the close of the present Session of Congress, or about that Time. Mr Lowrie brought me three Resolutions of the Senate—one advising the Ratification of the Treaty with Sweden, and one, of the Convention with the Hanseatic Cities— The third was a Call asking for Mitchell’s map, and the map marked A. referred to in the Protocols of Mr Gallatin’s late Conferences with the British Plenipotentiaries. Mr Barnard, a member of the House of Representatives from New-York, came with Mr Rochester, the Charge d’Affaires to the central Republic, Guatemala, who is going with lingering step to Norfolk to embark for the Post of his destination— This Gentleman was at the last Election of Governor of New-York, a Candidate for that office against De Witt Clinton; and has an earnest craving to be a candidate again— Blunt told me yesterday, that if he should be here; he would be the Candidate; but upon the vulgar adage that a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush, he goes for Guatemala, looking back to New-York—like Reynolds’s Picture of Garrick between Tragedy and Comedy— Coll. Roberdeau came with an Englishman from Yorkshire named Broadmeadow, who had a small model in brass of an improved Steam engine of his own invention; for which he is applying to Congress for a Patent— He had the boiler about one third filled with water; and by placing under it a lighted lamp of Alcohol, soon set it boiling and the machinery in Motion. It went very well, and with great rapidity. He took the steam channel to pieces, and shewed its construction— Its peculiarity consists in four apertures with valves, two of which are opened, and two are shut, by the same rising and descending stroke of the Piston. It simplifies very much the machine, and he says makes it impossible for the boiler to burst; which is not so clear— He is like most of our inventors in this Country very illiterate, and makes strange avock of the king’s Henglish. He is also like other inventors greatly captivated with his own achievement, and apparently with more reason than many others. The Steam engine is doubtless yet susceptible of great improvements, and none can be happier than
those which disarm it of danger— Mr Richard Peters junr, called, having come recently from Harrisburg. He expects the appointment of Reporter, of the decisions of the Supreme Court of the U.S. which is conferred by the Judges— The Court are to meet next Monday— Peters thinks the Tariff question will much affect the politics of Pennsylvania; but has less confidence of success in that State than he had— The expectation of success there is hope against demonstration— Coll Washington, Member of the House, from Maryland, came with Dr Wilson of Rockville, and a Mr Smith— Dr Wilson enquired after my Son George, whom he attended as a physician when he broke his arm at Rockville. Mr Southard informed me that the Ship Delaware, had arrived at Annapolis, but the roads are so bad that he doubted whether he should visit her as he had intended— He told me he heard Mr Van Buren intended to oppose the confirmation of the appointment of R. Tillotson as District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York; both on the ground of incompetency; and of questioned integrity— Received this day the Address of the Administration Convention held at Harrisburg the 4th and 5th. They nominated R. Rush, for the Vice-Presidency.
9. V. Round Capitol Square. Fog. Frost. Clear— Rain. Snow. Drawing-Room.

A Mr Simpson of Georgetown came with a subscription paper, for Coll. M’Kenney’s Indian tour, of which he had a printed copy. I declined the subscription but agreed to take a copy of the Book. Mr Everett came at the request of General Van Rensselaer to speak of the appointment of U.S. District-Attorney for the Southern District of New-York. I thought I had sent in the name of Robert Tillotson for re-appointment, but found upon examination that it had been omitted— His commission expired the 5th. of this Month— I told Mr Everett that before nominating another person I should deem it necessary to ascertain, whether Tillotson desired to be renominated, and also to apprize him that there would be objections against his re-appointment, which would require explanations from him. I had also some conversation with Mr Everett, about a resolution, offered yesterday in the house of Representatives by James Hamilton of South-Carolina, that Alston should be appointed to paint a Picture of the Battle of New-Orleans, to fill one of the vacant Pannels in the Rotunda of the Capitol—one of the Reasons that he assigned for which was that Alston, and General Jackson, were both natives of South-Carolina— This picture was part of the Canvas for Jackson, and Hamilton, who fancies himself equal to five Cicero’s, flourished in a Speech about Alston’s restoring the Augustan age of painting— Ingersoll of Connecticut moved to strike out the name of the Painter, leaving the selection of him to the Library Committee, to whom Hamilton proposed that his Resolution should be referred. Hamilton finding that his South-Carolina feather had tickled a tender point, ungraciously enough agreed to accept this amendment of Ingersoll— Kremer of Pennsylvania was delighted with the proposal to empannel the Battle of New-Orleans; but moved as an Amendment that the Artist should be employed also to paint another Picture to be placed alongside of the Battle namely the Hartford Convention, in secret Session— The Speaker pronounced this amendment to be not in order— Everett proposed an Amendment enlarging the Powers of the Committee, to the filling of the four vacant pannels, and Storrs moved that in the Selection of the Subjects there should be a due proportion of the tribute paid to the naval Achievements of our History— After the hour allowed by the Rules for debating Resolutions was passed, Hamilton moved a suspension of the rule
to continue the debate— Randolph came into the House, just in time to say I hope not— There was a considerable majority for suspending the Rule; but not two thirds; so that the House adjourned leaving the whole subject afloat— The subject was this day resumed and occupied the House the whole day— The amendments were all rejected by considerable majorities, and the Resolution itself by a vote of 103 to 98— Mr Bailey was here and made some enquiries concerning the Treaty with Sweden, and some claim of an allowance in the Accounts of J. J. Appleton while he was Charge d’Affaires in Spain— Mr Bryan Member of the House from North-Carolina, introduced General M’Donnell and Mr Mason of that State— The General is an applicant for the appointment of Collector at Edenton. Mr Mason is a Clergyman— Mr W. H. Allen from Florida, paid me a visit— Mr Amies the Papermaker at Philadelphia, presented me a Ream of his Folio Post, and a Ream of his Letter-paper; pay for which he declined to receive. Mr Rush called with several papers relating to Appointments of sundry Officers of the Customs— He also spoke of the nomination of himself for the Vice-Presidency at the recent Harrisburg Convention; and enquired what my impressions were respecting it.— He said his own course in relation to it would much depend upon my views, and those of the members of the Administration— I told him candidly that so far as I had been consulted by the friends of the Administration, I had advised that the Selection should be made of a Citizen residing South of the Potowmack— This had been fully considered; and had ultimately been judged not indispensable. The Harrisburg Convention having made the nomination, I hoped it would be universally accepted, and supported; and I assured him that no nomination could have made more pleasing to me— I added that I had received his Letters at the interval of a year from each other expressing his wish to retire from the Treasury Department, and for a Mission abroad— So far as these wishes were founded upon the state of his health, the overcharge upon him of public duty, I felt every disposition to gratify him, but that speaking as his friend I thought his own interest, and that of the Nation would be much better served by his remaining in this Country, instead of his going again abroad— He had more opportunities of bringing himself advantageously before the Public— He was daily acquiring a character in the mind of the Nation and assuredly no such Reports as his, had appeared from the Secretary of the Treasury since those of Hamilton had been made— He appeared to be much affected by these words of kindness and expressed his readiness to acquiesce in the nomination— Mr Joseph Blunt dined with us, and in the Evening we had the third Drawing Room—12. Senators, about forty members of the House, and many Strangers were present— The weather very bad— I sent to the Senate Message N. 13. with Mitchell’s map, and the map marked A—and signed 100 Blank Patents— Mrs Hay and her daughter were at the Drawing-Room.
10. V— Round Capitol Square.

Mr Marks a Senator from Pennsylvania, came to speak in behalf of Mr Condy Raguet, who is here out of place, very anxious to get in again; and somewhat apprehensive that this may not happen so soon as would be agreeable to him. I gave Mr Marks in full confidence and frankness my opinion of Mr Raguet’s conduct; and the history of his successive appointments as consul, informal political Agent, and Chargé d’Affaires— The rashness and violence of his proceedings and correspondence before his final explosion— The total want of judgment in the occasion that he took to demand his Passports and come home— The danger of War that he had incurred, and the embarrassment, into which he had drawn this Government, by his heedless impetuosity— I said that believing his motives to have been pure and patriotic, I had sustained him to the utmost extent of my power and conscience— I had passed no censure upon him— I had so stated in my message to Congress, and in the subsequent Correspondence with the Brazilian Government I had avoided any avowal of dissatisfaction with him, which would have given them a triumph, over him— But to replace in diplomatic service abroad a man
of such a temper and want of judgment who took blustering for bravery and insolence for energy was too dangerous— I could not in conscience do it— There might be no necessity for saying this to him— It may suffice to say there is no vacant office to which he could be appointed; But if he is disposed to have explanations and public disclosures I shall not object to them; and I said if Mr. Marks wished a more specific idea of the character of Mr Raguets Correspondence, and would call at the Department of State, it would all be shewn to him— He said he had information enough, and should simply inform Mr Raguet that there was no vacant Office— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me five Resolutions of that Body— Three being confirmations of Nominations, one the advice to ratify the Commercial Convention with Great Britain, and one an Enquiry whether my Message of 31. December, and the Documents, relating to the Slave Indemnity Convention, may be published without detriment to the public Service. Coll. Dwight brought and gave me to read a Letter from Lemuel Shaw of Lanesborough, highly commendatory of Mr Rush’s last Annual Treasury Report and also of the Message. Mr. Southard introduced a Mr Berry as a New-Jersey farmer— General Macomb a Mr Balch from Alabama; son of the Presbyterian Clergyman at Georgetown— Mr Cutts the second Comptroller brought some Accounts of Coll. M’Kenney, for expenditures in his Indian Negotiations which Cutts thought not sufficiently vouched. There was a lumping charge of near 5000 dollars for travelling expenses and presents to Indians without specification or voucher—but an order upon it for payment by the Secretary of War— Cutts said this never had been the practice, but was a new pretension of M’Kenney’s within a year or two— He thought it not warranted by Law, and could not pass the account. The pretension was that the whole appropriation for contingencies of the War Department was a discretionary fund at the disposal of the Secretary and requiring no voucher for settlement but his order— Cutts said the expenditure was no doubt discretionary but the account must be vouched like others. I thought him right, and desired him to make a written statement of his objection to M’Kenney’s Account. Mr Jacob Adams of Baltimore called, and afterwards came and dined with us— There was an Evening party at the Dutch Minister Huygens’s, which the young Ladies and John attended— J. W. Taylor spent part of the Evening with me conversing upon the subjects now in discussion before Congress. He mentioned also the result of the Meetings here concerning the Vice-Presidency and the acquiescence of all the friends of the Administration in the nomination of Mr Rush. He spoke also of Letters that he had received from James Tallmadge; and of his friendly, though somewhat unsatisfied dispositions— I signed 25 blank Soldiers Land grants.
11— V. Round Capitol Square— Weekly dinner.

Mr Sergeant came with young Mr Bayard of Philadelphia—and Mr Post the Minister of the second Presbyterian Church, and Chaplain to the house of Representatives, with Mr Bailey who brought a Letter of recommendation from Captain Partridge of the Military Academy at Middletown— Mr Bailey was some time a Tutor at that Institution when it was at Norwich, Vermont, and lately was a settled Minister at Pittsfield, Massachusetts— His connection with that Society was dissolved by an Ecclesiastical Council last September, and he now applies for the appointment of Chaplain at Old Point Comfort a Southern Residence being necessary to his Health— I referred him to the Secretary of War. Major Nourse the Chief Clark of that Department came and took a bundle of Papers relating
to the annuities of the Seneca Indians— Coll. M’Kenney came to ask for my decision upon a petition from Thomas Forsith and Richard Chabert, for a confirmation by me of the Will of a Potawatami Indian named Abraham Burnett, bequeathing to them two Sections of Land which had been reserved to him by the Treaties of St. Mary’s of 1816. and of the Wabash of 1826— The Will is very irregular in its Execution— The bequests contain no words of inheritance, and the name of one of the divisees, is written in the Will Shubare, intended no doubt for Chabert. M’Kenney further said that these devises were contested by the heirs of Burnett— I told Mr M’Kenney that the Confirmation of the Will was not within my authority— It was of judicial cognizance. My power was limited to granting permission for the conveyance of the Land— I suspended the decision for further enquiry. Dr Watkins called to recommend Joseph Blunt for the appointment of District Attorney for the Southern District of New York— I had much conversation with him on the subject—on the various candidates recommended, and on the several Considerations which must be weighed in making the selection— Mr Rush was here, and read a Letter to him from the Chairman of the Committee on Finance of the Senate, calling on him for facts and opinions, upon a proposition for the reduction of duty Bonds— He said that of these Calls from Committees, there were now about five times more than at the last Session of Congress— They were harrassing and vexatious— The Committees of Ways and Means and of Commerce in the House and of Finance in the Senate, were sending them in constant succession— Sometimes the Committees of both Houses making in substance the same calls and requiring double labour to be answered. All these sometimes are pursued too in a Spirit of Hostility to the Administration, and with purposes of factious opposition— I sent to the Senate Message N. 14. answering the enquiry in their Resolution of yesterday by expressing the opinion that the Message and Documents sent the 31st. of December last may be published without detriment to the public Service— Weekly dinner William Armstrong junr.Ichabod Bartlett, Isaac C. Bates, Alden Bradford, Tristam and Mrs Burges, Robert Desha, Clement Dorsey, Samuel A Foot, Daniel G. and Mrs Garnsey, George E. and Mrs Gilmer, Captain Basil and Mrs Hall, William H. Harrison, Gabriel Holmes, Josiah S. and Mrs Johnston, Captain Thomas ap Catesby Jones, Adam King, Robert P. Letcher, George M and Mrs Owen, William Smith, Andrew Stewart, Benjamin Swift, Miss Taylor, John Tyler, Miss Van Pradelles, Tobias Watkins, Silas Wood, David and Mrs Woodcock—with 7 in the family 31. at table— After the company were gone, I returned to my chamber, and wrote from ten till midnight—an exceedingly irksome operation, which I have scarcely ever resolution after a dinner or evening party to accomplish.
12. V. Round Capitol Square.

Moses Schwartz was a wandering Jew beggar with an Armenian dress and a long beard, and looking much like an imposter: but carrying about a recommendation and certificate signed by a number of respectable names telling for him a story of misfortune, loss and poverty, which in all such cases I am obliged to take for true— Mr Newton, Member of the House, from Norfolk, came with the Revd. Mr Ducachet of that place whom he introduced, and who told me upon enquiry that he proposed to preach to-morrow at St. John’s Church. Mr Dorsey Member of the House from Maryland came to give an earnest recommendation of Mr Hebb, for an appointment as a Clerk in the Post-Office or in the Navy Department, in the expected event of vacancies. Former affluence—present indigence; twelve children—respectable connections; electioneering relatives, this is the routine of recommendation to Office; and all combined in behalf of Mr Hebb— I shewed Mr Dorsey the Message of President Madison to Congress of 7. February 1817. containing my
correspondence with the British Government, on the claim of indemnity for Slaves carried away by British Officers after the late War—and in which they were included under the denomination of property. He took a minute of the document for Mr Gurley who is to speak in a debate now pending in the House of Representatives, involving that principle— Mr Rush was twice here— He read me his answer to the Committee of Ways and Means, relating to a reduction of duties upon Wines and Teas— It proposes a reduction of the duty upon Madeira Wine from one dollar to half a dollar a gallon—and upon Sherry from 60 Cents also to half a dollar. We had some discussion upon the policy, of levying the same duty upon those two Wines; which I questioned— He also brought me from the Department of the Treasury the names of several persons to be nominated for appointments to Offices— He spoke again of his own prospects and wishes—and said he had been entirely convinced of the truth and Justice of my observations to him last Wednesday— But that since then in considering how deeply his health was affected by the excessive and unremitting labours of the Department, he thought it would be impossible for him to sustain them even one year longer, and that he would be glad to accept the Mission to London, or any other abroad in which a vacancy might occur— This change since Wednesday, though somewhat unexpected, does not surprize me— There is obviously other cause for it, besides the state of his health, which was the same then as now— And the other cause is such as he does not incline to alledge to me— I can easily conjecture what it is— The preference of the Harbour to the Tempest— I told him that such being his wishes I should do all in my power to gratify them— That it was not my intention to nominate a Minister to Great-Britain till towards the close of the present Session of Congress. That in the interval, circumstances might occur to change the aspect of things at home or abroad. That if an appointment should then be made, it would be with full consideration of what was due from me to him, and to what he might then desire— Mr Wright, Member of the House from Ohio, introduced a Mr Collier of that State. Mr Storrs, member from New-York, brought me a Letter from A. B. Johnson of Utica, recommending James Platt for the Office of Postmaster at that place— Storrs himself joined in the recommendation, and denied that Platt was an opposition man, which I told him I had heard said, and which I added was rather the objection of our friends than mine— Two persons, I believe members of the House of Representatives from Tennessee, came with a Petition signed by the District Judge, Clark, Attorney, Marshall, and many other respectable names, and enclosed to me, in a Letter signed by the two Senators from Tennessee, White and Eaton. It was for the pardon of a man named Martin H. W. Mahon, sentenced last June by the U.S. Circuit Court to ten years imprisonment for stealing from the Mail while acting as Postmaster a Prize Lottery ticket of 1000 dollars— The reasons assigned are his youth, respectable connections, wife and children, poverty, and especially his state of health, and probable death before long— After stating to these gentlemen, the aggravated nature of the Offence, and the danger of relaxing the punishment of it, as well as my resistance to other applications of a similar character, I said the Signatures were so respectable and the arguments from the mans state of health so urgent, that I would take a few days for consideration, and would give a definitive Answer next week— Mr M’Kenney introduced a Mr Winthrop of New-York a nephew to the Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts. Mr M’Kenney brought also another application for permission to convey Lands reserved to Indians. Colonel Abert, came with and introduced Dr. Harlan of Philadelphia— A Mr Kessler of Frederick came with a young man of Georgetown named Upperman. Kessler said his motive for calling was when he returned home, to be able to tell his neighbours that he had seen the President— Evening party at the Mexican Ministers, Obregon— Attended by the young Ladies, and my Son.
13. V. Sunday.

Mr Southard called this morning with two papers, connected with a Report of an amended System of Navy Regulations that he is preparing in answer to a Resolution and Call of the Senate at their last Session— He is going to-morrow to Baltimore, and thence to Annapolis to visit the Delaware Line of Battle ship. At St John’s Church Mr Mason a Clergyman from Virginia read Prayers for the first Sunday after the Epiphany, and Mr Ducachet of Norfolk preached from Daniel 5.5.6–25.30— 5. [“]In the same hour came forth a finger of a man’s hand, and wrote over against the Candlestick, upon the plaister of the wall of the king’s Palace: and the king saw the part of the hand that wrote. 6. Then the king’s countenance was changed, and his thoughts troubled him, so that the joints of his loins were loosed, and his knees smote one against another. 25. And this is the writing, that was written MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN. 30. In that Night was Belshazzar the king of the Chaldeans slain”— The divisions of the discourse were drawn from the first words of the text “In the same hour”—what hour?— The hour of his security— The hour of his danger— The hour of his heedless and sacrilegious indulgence— The hour of his ruin— With an eloquent exposition of each of these properties as appertaining to that hour the preacher interwove an historical account of that astonishing Catastrophe of the Chaldean Empire—taken partly from the context in this 5th. Chapter of Daniel, and partly from cotemporaneous profane history— In remarking upon the kings security he described the Wall of Babylon as surrounding the City 350 feet high and 37 feet thick, with gates of iron, well guarded with soldiers— In illustrating the hour of danger, he described the manner in which the City was taken, by draining the bed of the Euphrates, and by marching two divisions of the besieging army from the two opposite points of the City, till they met at the royal palace— In commenting upon the hour of luxurious indulgence, he reprobated severely the sacrilegious use of the holy vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar from the Temple of Jerusalem, and spoke with solemn rebuke of the practice of dissolute and riotous banqueting by men in public Stations— The discourse closed with a vivid and forcible application of the subject to the unrepenting Sinners among his auditory, whom he conjured to lay all the instructions of this awful example to their hearts—“and then, live unrepenting if you can, and die unrepenting if you dare.” The very closing words of a Sermon that I heard at Albany in 1818 from the late Mr Larned of New-Orleans— Mr Ducachet’s delivery is excellent, and his Sermon was heard with great interest, and the deepest attention— After the morning Service I had a visit from Mr Joseph Blunt, who urged me with logical argument, and persuasive importunity to nominate him for U.S. District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York. He also borrowed the third Number of the American Quarterly Review— In the afternoon Prayers were read at St. John’s Church by Mr Ducachet, and the Sermon was preached by Mr Mason, from Job. 19.25. “For I know that my Redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand at the latter day, upon the Earth. 26. And though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shall I see God. 27. Whom I shall see for myself, and mine eyes shall behold, and not another.”— Mr Mason considered this text as a direct prophesy of the Advent of Jesus Christ, and a direct assertion of a future State, and of the Resurrection of the body— So it is considered in the burial Service of the Church of England. In the English Bible the passage scarcely admits of any other Construction, but it is not so in the original. Mr Mason’s Sermon however was upon the certainty of a future State, as revealed in the Scriptures; for the mode of which he cited the memorable passage of St. Paul 1. Corinthians 15.42.43.44— The Subject of the Discourse is no doubt of the deepest interest, but was not treated in a manner so affecting as the fate of Belshazzar had been made in the morning. Mr Mason’s composition though good is not equal to that of Mr Ducachet— His most vigorous efforts leave his hearer cold— I did not attend Church in the Evening. Abigail S. Adams dined at Mr Elliot’s— An incipient inflammation in my left eye, discouraged me for the first part of the Evening, but I afterwards read Thomson’s Translation of Job 19.25.26.27. and Hewlett’s Comment upon that part of the English Bible— Neither sustains Mr Mason’s construction

Governor Barbour called to introduce his Son in law Taliaferro, who has just arrived from the South— His wife has been already some time at her fathers— Mr Clay brought two Notes from Mr Rebello the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires, with several Documents relating to the entry of two Buenos-Ayrean Privateers into our Ports. Also despatches received from Joel R. Poinsett our Minister to Mexico— He also read me a Letter from P. B. Porter at Albany; and spoke of the proceedings of the Anti-Jackson Convention at Richmond; who he said had nominated Mr Rush for the Vice Presidency— And he mentioned a publication of the Jackson central Committee, and signed by J. P. Van Ness, promising a reply to his, Clay’s Address, and inviting testimony to confidential communications— And he said he expected that by misrepresentations and falsehood, they would furnish a Show of Evidence— This was the day of the annual meeting of the Supreme Court of the United States— Chief Justice Marshall and the judges, Washington, Johnson, Story and Trimble, paid me a morning visit with the Marshal Ringgold. Judge Thompson had called before; and Judge Duval had not arrived— I desired Judge Story to say to Judge Thompson, that I should be glad to see him, upon the subject of the appointment of a District Attorney at New-York— He had promised Mr Clay to write to Mr Tillotson, and ascertain whether he intended to decline a re-appointment, or to risk a re-nomination. General Brown called upon me, in the deepest dejection of Spirits; and told me that he came for that purpose—he had about six years since a parolytic shock, and has been ever since in very precarious health— Still flattering himself with hopes of recovery, until about two months past when he had again a severe attack, which has left him in this state of prostration and despair He told me that he wished his earthly Scene was over; and should terminate it himself but that it was his duty not to desert his Post; and intimated that he would resign his Commission, but that his Circumstances are such that it would leave his family destitute—and said he had not opened his lips, in this respect to any human being, except his wife; but he thought it would be proper, that he should make known this his sense of his own Condition to me. I endeavoured to cheer him, by attributing this pressure upon his Spirits, to the weather which for several weeks has been and still continues damp, and gloomy, and full of fogs and vapours; and said that with the return of a clear sky and bracing atmosphere, he would recover his Spirits, and better health; and at all events he would be prepared to receive the dispensations of Providence with composure and firmness—

lg.l: Why should I grieve, when grieving I must bear?
And take with guilt, what guiltless I may share.

div.p:
he appeared to be partially soothed with these observations, the justness of which he admitted: and he asked me if I had read his answer to a Call from the House of Representatives, asking about the reasons, authority and expense of a late dislocation and exchange of Stations, between the two divisions of the army; made by his Orders—a movement which has met with some censure— I had read his answer, which bears some indications of a wounded Spirit— I had a visit from a Mr Goldsborough, who said he had been introduced to me at Baltimore, and also here. He is employed as a contractor at the fortifications in progress at Old Point Comfort Fortress Monroe, and fortress Calhoun. Major Nourse called for the proceedings of the Militia
Court-Martial at Mobile in 1814.— I had them not—and he afterwards called and told me that he had found them— J. W. Taylor was here in the Evening— He spoke of the next New-York annual Election which he observed would be a general one, for Governor, for the Legislature—for Sheriffs, for Congress, and for Electors of President and Vice-President— He believed the success of all would depend upon the Selection of Candidate for Governor, the Spirit of the New-York Elections having always governed by local feelings. He said it was understood that the combined Van Buren and Clinton party had fixed upon the Comptroller Marsy for their Candidate, and he thought the best person to oppose him by the friends of the Administration would be Judge Thompson— That he might perhaps feel some reluctance at giving up his Office as Judge of the Supreme Court, for the uncertain prospect of an election which if successful would be only for two years, and at the end of that time might leave him destitute— It had occurred to him, Taylor, that from the intimacy that had subsisted between Judge Thompson and me, as Associates in the last Administration, I might perhaps have some influence in forming his determination, and particularly by presenting to him the prospect; that if after two years Service as Governor, he should not be re-elected, an Office of adequate indemnity should be given him under the Government of the Union— I said this was a proposal, upon which I should wish for time to reflect, before giving a definitive answer. In its first aspect it appeared to me liable to objections, first as an unsuitable interference in the Election of Governor of New-York— Secondly, as it would require a pledge from me to Judge Thompson, which in itself might be deemed exceptionable, and which it might not be in my power to redeem. His place upon the Bench if vacated, must be immediately supplied, by a Citizen of the same State or section of the Union; which would necessarily exclude him, until a new vacancy of that same seat— The Offices of Collector and Postmaster at New-York, were scarcely to be thought of for him; nor was there any prospect to be relied upon that they or either of them would be vacant at the time— What Office was there that I could give him reason to expect? He said a foreign Mission— I replied that I could have no certainly that there would be any Mission abroad vacant at the time, and if there should, I could scarcely engage it in anticipation, so as to preclude myself from Selection of the person to fill it. And this consideration was the more forcible, inasmuch as Judge Thompson’s life and experience have not been diplomatic— I said also that Judge Thompsons situation was favourable for being a Candidate, as in the event of failure he would still hold his present Office, and could not be removed from it— Even in the event of failure, he would come so near to success that it would rather add to his standing in Society; and in the event of success it could scarcely be doubted that he would be secure of re-election— There was much more of this Conversation, and Taylor said he should give up the idea of pursuing his suggestion further— I said that Judge Thompson would be an excellent Candidate for them, and I had no doubt would prove an able Governor; and I indicated to him a source of influence to persuade him, of which he said he would avail himself: and I urged him, if Judge Thompson should decline, to think of Mr Sanford— He said the feelings of the friends of the Administration in New-York, were embittered against Sanford; not only from his persevering, and inflexible refusal to take any part in the measures which they were pursuing to sustain the Administration, but for his vote at the commencement of the present Session of Congress with regard to the choice of a Printer to the Senate— I said the vote was susceptible of explanation— Mr Sanford was not unfriendly to the Administration, though he had not chosen to make active exertions as a friend— But if elected Governor of New-York, he would have no Spirit of hostility to the Administration, and the neutrality of his course hitherto, would perhaps be more favourable to his success than if he had been more anxiously devoted to our Cause— Taylor did not seem to be convinced; but the subject may be resumed— I received a Letter from George, with his Account— The last two days I have suffered with an inflammation of my eyes, which threatens to disqualify me for reading and writing— That is from all the consolation that I can promise myself in my remnant of life— Received Letters from my brother announcing the death of Ward N. Boylston. at 1. O’Clock A.M. of the 7th. instt.

Mr Shepherd brought a subscription paper for an Edition printed at Philadelphia of Malte-Bruns Geography to which I declined signing my name—having already part of the Book as published in numbers at Boston. Mr M’lean member of the House from Ohio, introduced two persons from that State, the name of the second of whom I am not sure of having set down correctly— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution advising the ratification of the North-eastern boundary Convention with Great Britain— Mr Merwin, member from Connecticut and Swift from Vermont, called concerning a petition to Congress from a man named Brown, imprisoned under an Execution at the suit of the United States, for debt; which Petition Mr Swift had sent to me— I told Mr Swift that I could not act upon it, as it claimed balances as due from the U. States to the Petitioner, by credits for which he produced neither voucher nor Evidence— I said if his Petition was addressed to me it should simply state that he was in prison by an Execution in behalf of the United States, which he is unable to pay—and he should further obtain a certificate of his inability to be endorsed upon his Petition, by the Attorney of the United States for the District— Mr Swift took part of the papers with him and I afterwards sent him the remainder— Mr A. H. Powell, called and introduced a relative of his own name, and another person from Virginia; and Mr Sanford the Senator from New-York called with a young man of that State; returning from the South— Mr Tracy of Norwich, Connecticut was here; and Dr Jemison, the half-breed Seneca Indian, who has passed an Examination, for an appointment of Surgeon’s Mate in the Navy— He came to remonstrate against the Treaty of last Summer, which they alledge to have taken away from the New-York Indians Lands which they had purchased under the Sanction of the Government of the U. States, at Green Bay— And he complained that it was not the first time that the Indians of the Six Nations had been thus treated— Mr Sparks also was here, and informed me that he proposed to embark on the first of March at Boston for Liverpool: intending to pass a year in England and France in search of Documents relating to our Revolutionary War. We had a small company of Gentlemen to dine. Coll. John J. Abert, Rufus G. Amory, James Bayard, Joseph Blunt, Mr Burns, Benjamin Gorham, the Revd. Mr Mason, Richard Peters junr and Mr Sparks; with seven in the family 16 at table. Invitations had also been sent to the Revd Mr Ducachet, to J. Sergeant, and Captain Jones of the Navy who could not come— I sent Message N. 2. to the House of Representatives, with a Report from the Secretary of State, in answer to a Resolution of Enquiry concerning the recovery of debts in Mexico, from debtors absconding from the United States, and concerning the boundary— And Message to the Senate N. 15 with three nominations— I also signed an order for the appointment of J. W. Holmes, to be keeper of the Light House at Charleston South-Carolina—in place of John Calhoun deceased. I was quite unwell all the after part of this day and Evening; with a dull headache, and the inflammation of my eyes; which disabled me from reading or writing— There was an Evening party at Mr Boulignys which the younger part of my family attended— I took a foot bath and retired early to bed— The perpetual succession of visitors from breakfast to dinner crazes me; but there is nothing so deeply alarms me as this inflammation of my eyes— I am endeavouring to arm my breast for whatever may await me—but

lg.l: “Who can hold a fire-brand in his hand
By thinking of the frosty Caucasus.”

div.p:
Mr Graham came to ask for the final direction concerning the Land-Office in the State of Ohio; which I gave that it should be fixed at Tiffin— He also enquired if I had come to a determination upon his claim for compensation, upon the Settlement of Indian Superintendence Accounts. I had not. Mr Lowrie, Secretary of the Senate brought me four Resolutions of that body confirming appointments; one of them that of Moses Myers, Collector at Norfolk, against which Tazewell made ineffectual opposition— Mr Leffler, member of the House from Virginia introduced a Mr Ray from that State, who was of the late Convention at Richmond. Judge Thompson called, and I spoke with him concerning the appointment of a District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York— He told me that he had written to Mr Tillotson, as he had promised Mr Clay, to enquire whether he wished to be renominated, but had not received his answer. But he said that Mr Tillotson had repeatedly told him he should decline a renomination— I then enquired of Judge Thompson his opinion, concerning the several candidates who had been recommended. John Duer, Blunt, Ogden Edwards, D. B. Ogden, Tallmadge, and Baldwin— He said they were all well qualified, but he thought the best appointment, upon the whole, would be judge Edwards— He spoke favourably of all excepting Duer, and nothing to his disadvantage; but that the signatures of so large a number of the New-York delegation in the House of Representatives, were obtained by the solicitations of William Duer, of Albany, and by the exertions of Verplanck and Bunker, family connections of the Duer’s— He added that judge Edwards had varied in his inclination for the Office of Attorney, until several those who would prefer him had signed in favour of Duer—but that four or five of them had declared they would have recommended Edwards in preference, had they known he was a candidate— In the Evening I received from Judge Thompson a Letter to him from Tillotson declaring that he wrote by the same mail to Mr Clay, requesting not to be renominated— I had morning visits also from Mr Powell, who introduced Mr Steenberger and Mr Arthur, from Virginia. The Address of the Convention to the People came this day, written by Chapman Johnson, and much admired. Mr John W. Weems brought me a Letter from his father John C Weems a member of the House from Maryland, earnestly recommending him for an appointment. Mr Cobb, Senator from Georgia came to urge the transmission to Congress as soon as possible of a Message, concerning the boundary between Georgia and Florida— I told him that I would send the message as soon as two copies of the Papers and of the map should have been made out; and they were now making— He said he had supposed this would occasion some delay and he had brought back the copy of papers which I had sent to him and his Colleague, which might serve for one of the copies to be sent to Congress— Mr Thomas, a Senator from Illinois came to have conversation with me; but on Mr Clay’s coming in shortly after, went away. Mr Clay took the papers, relating to the complaints of Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires, to answer his Notes— Mr Clay mentioned that when the Senate shall have acted upon the Northwestern boundary Convention with Great-Britain, it would be necessary to send a messenger with the ratified Conventions— He said there was a young man named Herbert, recommended by judge Washington, a relation of his and my Son George, whom Mrs. Adams had requested him to send— He was altogether willing to send him, but thought he could not do it without my consent. I said we would wait to decide, until we ascertain what the Senate will do with the Northwestern boundary Convention; but painful as it is to me to controul the wishes of my wife, I cannot consent to this proposal— Governor Barbour brought me the papers respecting the accounts of T. L. M’Kenney in
his Indian Negotiations, which are contested by the second Comptroller Cutts— Also the application of Lieutenant George S. Greene for a Court of Inquiry on a Quarrel between him and Lieutt. Wheelock last April at West-Point—and his answer persisting in the refusal to grant a Court— Mr Asa Rogerson the Collector at Camden North-Carolina, came to inquire of the causes of the suspension of his nomination to the Senate— I referred him to the Treasury Department. He asked after a Letter in his favour from General Iredell in his favour transmitted as he said by Mr Macon. I told him I supposed he would find it at the Treasury. He was inquisitive as to the persons who opposed his appointment, upon which I declined gratifying him, but told him he should not be condemned without an opportunity to justify himself: which he said was all he asked— Resumed my writing in the Evening; with great difficulty. Party at Mr Clay’s— None of our family out— Signed Ratification of Treaty with Sweden. 17th.

Returning from my daily morning walk round the Capitol Square, I met a man shabbily clad who accosted me, and said he had been to the President’s House to see me— I shook hands with him; told him I was glad to see him and enquired his name— He said it was Skinner, that he belonged to a Cotton factory near Baltimore— There were many there, and they had told him that if he came here I would not see, and speak with him, and that was all he wished in calling upon me. Mr Vance a Member of the House introduced a Mr Meeker of that State, who he said had come with a drove of Hogs to Richmond, Virginia, and then came on to visit Washington— Mr Taliaferro, member of the House from Virginia came with Mr Scott, who is an applicant for Office, and brought with him Letters of recommendation from a large portion of the Virginia Delegation, and from Judge Washington— Governor Barbour called with a Resolution adopted yesterday by the House of Representatives calling for copies of the proceedings of the Mobile Court Martial on the Tennessee Militia men, and of all the Correspondence between the Secretary of War and the Governor of Tennessee on the subject. This Correspondence with the governor, he said was voluminous, and the Letters touching this subject contained also much matter relating to others, and he asked advice whether to send the whole of the Letters or extracts of what related to the term of Service of the Militia-men only— I thought the extracts would be sufficient— Mr Bartley, member of the House from Ohio, brought a Letter urging the fixation of the controverted Land-Office at Tiffin— I told him I had requested Mr Graham to give the final order for its location there by the first of May next— He said he had also received an abusive anonymous Letter against it, which he believed was written by Platt Brush. Mr Satterlee Clark brought me the written opinions of Mr Oakley and Mr Storrs upon the question of his removal as a Paymaster in the Army. He asked if it would be necessary for him to address to me a memorial on the same question. I thought he should— Mr Cutts, the second Comptroller came with the volume of the Army Laws, and some Accounts of T. L. M’Kenney, of Governor Duval of Florida, and of the Indian Agent Tipton, and stated to me the principles of his objections to their Accounts; but I had not had time to read the papers relating to this Controversy, left with me yesterday, by Governor Barbour— The question requires deliberate consideration, and great discretion in determining upon the principle to be hereafter pursued— Mr Dorsey, member of the House
from Maryland, introduced Mr Richard Dorsey and another friend— And Coll. Jones the Adjutant General, came with Lieutenant Coll. Lawrence of the third Regiment of Infantry. Coll. Roberdeau, brought me the two Copies of the map of the heads of St. Mary’s River, which are to be sent to Congress with the Communications, received from the Governor of Georgia. He also shewed me a Letter from W. Elliot, on some remarks indirectly censorious upon the Coll made by G. C. Verplanck a few days since in the House of Representatives— They were unjust, and the Coll. feels them severely.— A Mr King, a Juryman at the Circuit Court brought a recommendation of pardon signed by the Jurors and Judges, for a man named Peter Henneberg; this day convicted of Larceny, and sentenced to be whipped ten stripes and pay a fine of a dollar— I sent back the Paper, first for a Petition from the man himself and then for a Statement by the Clerk of the Court, of the Indictment upon which he was convicted— Johnson Hellen finally brought the paper, and I wrote upon it, an order that the pardon should issue. John asked this day my consent to his marriage next Month, which I took for consideration. He dined out at the Mexican Minister Obregon’s— And the young part of our family attended an evening party at Mr Frye’s.
18. IV:30. Sun rose 7:13. Walk round Capitol Square

General Van Rensselaer came again to urge the appointment of John Duer, as Attorney of the United States for the Southern District of New-York— He read me a Letter from Ogden Edwards to Duer, dated in September last, and encouraging Duer to make interest for himself by declaring a probability that he, would not apply for the office; preferring on the whole that which he holds of a State Judge— Joseph Butler brought me at last a petition for the discharge from prison of his brother Samuel; with the recommendation of Judges Cranch and Morsell, and of the District Attorney Swann, who had resisted before, and says he signs the recommendation reluctantly now— I signed the order for his discharge. Mr Fürst the Medalist, requested me to lend him the Portrait of my father, last painted by Stewart, for him to make from it the Die of a Medal. I dissuaded him from it, by saying that there was in this Country so little taste for Medals, that it would certainly be an unprofitable labour to him— He said he did not expect profit from it— But the Portrait was so admirable as a Representation of Old Age, that he wished to try the efficacy of his own Art in exhibiting the same thing. He would work upon it at his leisure; and without regard to or expectation of profit. I told him he should then have the Portrait; on condition of taking care that it shall receive no damage. He said he should want it for several months— Mr White the delegate from Florida, and Judge Brackenridge called together the Judge is returning, from Philadelphia to Pensacola. I invited them to this day’s dinner and they came— The Revd. Mr Williams, with Beard the Oneida Chief, and Dr Jemison, all half breed Indians came to take leave. Beard and Jemison are returning to New-York— Jemison came with Mr Garnsey, the member of the House from the District where the remnant of the six Nations yet abide— Commodore Rodgers came with Edward Pinkney, who is here from Baltimore, to prevail upon his brother Charles to go back there with him— He came to me to enquire if I could do any thing to save him— He has fallen into habits of intemperance. A young man of admirable parts; of quick perception, of great ingenuity and of elegant accomplishments, lost by this fatal propensity— I told his brother that I had done, and would yet do every thing for Charles that I could consistently with my own duties— That his place as Secretary of
