the Legation to Russia, had not been filled though he had been now nearly six months, in this Country— That he had no intention of returning to Russia, as he informed me that his physician had told him he would certainly lose his life if he should remain in that climate— That I had within a few days for the first time received a Letter from Mr Middleton, concerning him, and speaking of him in the most delicate and friendly manner— That the appointment of a Secretary to that Mission could not be long delayed, and that the possibility of bestowing any other appointment upon Charles Pinkney must depend upon his recovering entirely from his present habits— He asked if he might say this to his brother— I said certainly— He might assure him that nothing could be done for him while he gave himself up to such indulgences— Edward was anxious to be authorised to give him encouragement in the event of his reformation— I said I could give no expectations unless in the event of a total change of his habits, and I feared they were too deeply seated— Coll. Roberdeau introduced Mr Geddes and Mr Roberts who are employed on the Surveys for the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— He called a second time after having taken a Meridian observation with Mr W. Elliot— Mr M’lean the Postmaster General, called and took the papers relating to the appointments of Postmasters at Washington Pennsylvania, and at Utica New-York. He has appointed Mr Henderson at Washington, and I recommended to him Mr James Platt at Utica— He assented, but said it would occasion some clamour. Mr. Sparks came to take leave—being about to return to Boston, and intending to embark on the first of March for Europe— Mr Tyler called with Mr. Lyford who keeps the reading room at Norfolk. Mr Blunt came to renew his solicitation for the appointment of U.S. District Attorney at New-York. Mr Clay read to me a Letter from Peter B. Porter against Oakley whom he supposed to be a candidate. Governor Barbour took the papers relating to the demand of Lieutenant Greene for a Court of Enquiry. I thought it should be granted, for which I gave my reasons. That it could not be refused without denying him Justice— His claim under the Circumstances seemed to me a demand of positive right. Considerations of delicacy must give way before it— But if the Report of the Court of Enquiry should be against him I thought he might be dismissed without a Court Martial— We had also conversation upon the claim of Satterlee Clark to be still a District Paymaster. The Opinions of Messrs. Oakley and Storrs rest upon the single consideration of the deficiency of Evidence. Clark has nothing but the Letter of the Adjutant General C. J. Nourse, informing him, by Order of the Secretary of War, that the President had directed he should be dismissed from the Service— Oakley and Storrs say that the Act of dismission could be performed only by the President, and must be authenticated of Record as much as the Commission— But defect of evidence does not warrant the negation of the act— And Governor Barbour observed there was ample proof of the Act, in the subsequent appointment of another paymaster in the place of Mr Clark— I propose to refer the Papers to the Attorney General for his opinion— We spoke also of the question, of the second Comptroller R. Cutts, upon the Accounts of T. L. M’Kenney, Governor Duval and the Indian Agent Tipton. I thought a regulation would be necessary that no Officer on distant service should claim compensation for coming to Washington to settle his accounts, unless by Order from the Head of the Department. We had our weekly dinner party— Mark Alexander, James, Mrs and Miss Barbour, D. D. Barnard, T. H. and Mrs Benton, Mr Bleecker, H. M Brackenridge, John Branch, Richard A. Buckner, Saml Butman, R. V. De Witt, M. Dickerson, S. A. and Mrs Foot, W. Haile, Miss Harrow, Joseph Healey, Coll R. Jones, Captain T a C Jones, Coll Lawrence, John M’Kinley, Robert Orr junr.Condy and Mrs RaguetJoseph Richardson, Asher Robbins, W. B. Rochester, John SloaneSamuel L. and Mrs Southard, James Strong, John Taliaferro, Mr and Mrs Taliaferro, Judge Thompson, Mr and two Misses Wellford Joseph M. White Austin E. Wing, Mary Roberdeau and six in the family 33 at table.
19. V:30.— Round Capitol Square—

Coll. Thomas of New-York, introduced a Mr Williams, returning from the South to that City—who also brought me a Letter of introduction from Seth Hunt— Mr Bartley, member from Ohio, came with a Mr Fitch who delivered to me several testimonials favourable to the character of the inhabitants of Tiffin— Mr Lawrence, member from Pennsylvania introduced Mr Sadder (as I heard the name) and Mr Van Sickle of that State. Joseph Butler, brought me from the Department of State the Order for the discharge from Prison, of his brother Samuel which I signed— I also signed an order for the discharge of Samuel Snow convicted of gambling, and a pardon to Peter Henneburg, convicted of theft and sentenced to be whipped ten stripes— All these pardons are at the recommendation of judges, jurors or the District Attorney— I signed also the Proclamation of the Treaty with Sweden— and 13. Land grants from the General Land-Office—from which the Commissioner sends me almost every day two or three to sign— Mr Wilde, the new member from Georgia elected to supply the place of John Forsyth now Governor of the State paid a morning visit. Mr Stewart, member from Pennsylvania, introduced J. B. Trevor of that State; recently appointed a Director of the Bank of the United States, on the part of the Government— Mr Bell, a member from Tennessee, who last week, brought me the Petition for the pardon of Mahon, called for my answer— I told him that after full deliberation I had made up my mind that I could not consistently with my own sense of duty comply with the request of the Petition. The offence was stealing from a Letter in the mail, while acting as Post-master, a Lottery ticket entitled to a prize of 1000 dollars; a complicated crime, combining theft, and a breach of confidential public trust. A crime so dangerous in its consequences, and to which there is so great exposure of temptation, that Society has scarcely any guard against it, excepting in the severity of the punishment. That ten years imprisonment was scarcely adequate to it— That the respectability of the family and connections of the criminal shewing only the weight of influence bearing in his favour, afforded no sound reason for relaxation. that the only consideration urged in the petition which had induced me to hesitate was the state of the Prisoner’s health, and the danger to his life from confinement. But upon mature consideration I had concluded that this would still not justify a pardon, unless by assuming as a principle that in all cases sickness should operate as a discharge from prison—a result which the law certainly never contemplated. This man was sentenced only last june— The term of his imprisonment is for ten years— The risk of sickness and of death in such a term must apply to all cases, and a discharge of this man from prison now would be almost equivalent to a total remission of his punishment. Mr Bell admitted the force of these reasons, and said he would state them as correctly as he was able in answering the persons from whom he had received the Petition. I desired him to add that I had been equally rigorous upon every other applications for remission of punishment upon convictions for this offence; and that it would have been infinitely more agreeable to me, if I could have complied with the prayer of the Petition— Mr Foot called to take leave— Going next Monday for Albany. Mr Bates member from Missouri came to recommend the appointment of a Consul at Santa Fe in Mexico. There is a person so commissioned, but Mr Bates thinks he is not there, nor intending to go— He mentioned also some question between him and the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, concerning the issuing of Land-grants, upon which he wished to appeal to my decision. I said I would readily give it, if the question should be within my competency. He did not explain what it was.
Mr Everett introduced Mr Lawrence of Boston— J. Sergeant gave a morning Call. Mr Clay introduced Mr Israel, from Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. Mr Southard left with me a packet, containing nominations from the Navy Department to be submitted to the Senate, and papers from W. Pinkney Collector at Key West relating to the Seizure of 121 Slaves, brought into that Port from the wreck of a Spanish vessel— Mary Roberdeau left us and returned home— The House of Representatives met this day and immediately adjourned, on being informed of the decease of George Holcombe, one of the members from New-Jersey. He died at his home, Allentown, Monmouth County; on the 13th. not having been here this Session.
20. IV:30. Sunday— Sun rose 7:11.

Heard this morning Mr Kent, from James 1:13. “Let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted with evil; neither tempteth he any man.” In explaining the text he observed that, the word rendered in our translation to tempt, is used in the new testament, and particularly in this Epistle of James, with two distinct significations; under one of which it denotes trial of any kind; and under the other, its proper sense the trial of seduction to Sin— The Discourse was argumentative, and its object was to prove that there is no excuse for Sin— That there is inconsistency and hypocrisy in the pretence of those who would palliate their evil ways by imputing them to an overruling necessity. That the doctrine of the total depravity of human nature refutes itself; inasmuch as it acknowledges a consciousness of right and wrong, as universal in the being whom it changes with universal depravity— He alledged that without this consciousness there could be no depravity, and referred to the principle established in Courts of Justice, with regard to the acts of insane persons; who could never be convicted of crimes— He urged with great force this consciousness of right and wrong; first as a demonstration that the natural character of man was good; and that he commits evil only by doing violence to his nature; and secondly that there is no excuse for Sin. That man cannot throw off his moral responsibility, but is and must be an accountable creature— This is a good moral doctrine; but there are also great and powerful propensities in the heart of man to evil. These are admitted and asserted with so much emphasis in the Scriptures, that the general doctrine of goodness as appertaining to human nature, is not more countenanced than that of total depravity— Mr Kent’s mind is ingenious and he is not ineloquent. The principal defect of his oratory is too much effort, both in pronunciation, and in gesture. There should be very little action in the reading of a written discourse— In the afternoon at the Presbyterian Church I heard Mr from Luke 14.17. “And sent his servant at supper-time to say to them that were bidden Come; for all things are now ready.” This discourse was not written; and not much meditated— It was Calvinism, but of the most moderate and mitigated character. He read only part of the Chapter and of the parable, and commented only upon the invitation, and not upon the indignation or compulsion or exclusion with which it closes. The argument of the discourse was the application of the parable of the Supper to show the sufficiency of the Gospel dispensation to all the wants and purposes of man— Between the Services I called to see Mr Rush, who has been for some days confined to his chamber by indisposition. I received from him yesterday, enclosing one to him from his physician Dr Sim, advising him to withdraw from all attention to public business for a time, as absolutely indispensable in the present condition of his health. I told him that I not only consented to it, but added my earnest exhortations to those of Dr. Sim that he would. I received this day a Letter from Nathanl Curtis with a copy of Mr Boylston’s Will.
21. V:30.— Sun rose 7:10. Walk round Capitol Square

Mr Beecher, member from Ohio, came and introduced Mr Goddard of that State— Beecher is desponding and has misgivings of the steadiness even of Ohio. Mr Hyam came in behalf of a Mr T. H. Poppleton, an Englishman now at Baltimore, and who applies for employment as a civil-engineer, and sent on very respectable recommendations— Mr Lincoln is from Boston; here again upon the concerns of the late Columbian College. He continues to cherish hopes— Mr Bell, Senator from New-Hampshire came to say that Mr Benton was intending to make a great effort, against the ratification of the North-western boundary Convention with Great-Britain— That he would probably fail in this, because Tazewell did not sustain him, but was in favour of the ratification. Tazewell is however now absent, and it will be some time before he returns: it may therefore be two or three weeks, before the Senate will act definitively, upon the Convention— I have no reliance—either upon the good faith, or consistency of Tazewell; but I told Mr Bell, there was no occasion for hurrying the decision of the Senate— He said that upon the North-Eastern boundary Convention the Senators from Maine had been strongly inclined to oppose its ratification, untill Genl. Chandler was alarmed by the fear of his own responsibility in the event of its rejection— They did not venture therefore to push the opposition to that point; but contented themselves with voting alone against the advice to ratify. Mr Bell said that notwithstanding the friendly professions towards the Administration, he has no confidence in him— He will watch the signs of the Times, and will declare ultimately for the strongest side. Of such Summer friends I have multitudes— They constitute all majorities— Mr Archer, member from Virginia introduced two persons from that State, one named Dunlop, who remembered that he had met me at his brother’s in London. ArmstrongPeters and Carter came while I was engaged, so that I could not receive them. The Cabinet Meeting at one, all the members being present, was to determine upon the message to Congress, with the communications received from the Governor of Georgia, relating to the boundary between that State and Florida— Part of the papers were read; as were the Act of Congress of the 4th. of May 1826— The passages of Ellicott’s Journal shewing the line as drawn by him and the Spanish Commissioner Miner in 1797. and the Letter from T. M. Randolph late Commissioner on the part of the United States, announcing the suspension of proceedings by him and the Georgia Commissioner, by order of the Governor of that State. The question discussed was whether the message should express any opinion; or recommend to Congress any measure; or should be a mere communication of the papers— The latter was thought the most advisable, and I struck out the general recommendation which I had inserted in the draft of such measures as might conciliate the rights and interests of the United States and of the Territory of Florida, with those of Georgia— Governor Barbour brought with him the Treaty, recently concluded with the Creek Indians, ceding to the United States all the remnant of their lands in the State of Georgia— Also the papers relating to the Militia Court-martial at Mobile in 1814—called for by a Resolution of the House— There were among them some Letters from General Jackson; and question was made whether they should be sent with the rest— I thought not, as they were not embraced by the Resolution— Mr Pearce, member from Rhode-Island, and Mr Blunt were successively here in the Evening; and consumed it all— Blunt was urgent to great importunity, to obtain for himself the appointment of District Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He set forth all his services and all his sacrifices, which have been great, but he wants discretion; and the appointment of him would not be sustained by public opinion— I sent to Congress, Message N. 4. with the annual Report of the Director of the Mint.
22. V:45. Sun rose 7:9. Over N.E. Corner of Carusi’s Theatre.

Mr Thompson a Member of the House from New-Jersey came and introduced his Son, with Messrs.Russell and Brown of the same State— Mr Garnsey and Mr Threlkeld came, at the same time, though not together. Mr. Garnsey said that the Oneida Chief Beard, and the Clergyman Williams were not yet gone— Payment having been suspended at the Bank of some order for money that they had received; the Appropriation Bills not being yet passed. Mr Threlkeld left with me a written application signed by himself and several other magistrates of the District, requesting the appointment of an additional Justice of the Peace, and recommending Lewis Carbery— Mrs. Ariana F. Johnson came for the third time to solicit my influence with the Postmaster General to obtain for her husband an appointment of a Clerk in that Office— I had declined writing to him twice before, and declined again, but said if I should see Mr M’lean as in the course of a few days was probable I would speak to him of her husband— Mr Sloane, member of the House from Ohio, introduced a young Mr Burges, Son of the member from Rhode-Island. A Mr Dexter, a contractor upon the Delaware and Chesapeake Canal came alone— He said he expected the Canal would be finished by next July, but intimated that the funds would fail sooner, and that unless the Directors should obtain further aid from Congress the work would stop. Mr Biddle President of the Bank of the United States was here— He spoke of an extraordinary exportation within the last six weeks, of Silver: amounting he said to upwards of three Millions and he said it had reduced the amount of Specie in the Banks, so that they were obliged to be calling in their debts and checking their discounts which had given the alarm to the merchants. He mentioned also a Fancy Ball, projected at Philadelphia, and gave me a Message from Miss Mease to Mrs. Adams— Mr Tracy, member from New-York, and Dr Watkins, called together. Mr Tracy’s object was to ask of me a renewed declaration that I was not a freemason— I had already told him that I was not: and he made many apologies for repeating the question, but said that in the Western part of New-York this was now the only test of Elections, and he read me a part of a Letter from one of his friends; who wrote him that altho’ a positive denial had been published that I was a Mason, the assertion that I was had been republished with promises to produce extracts from the Books of the Lodge to which I belonged. This is a sample of electioneering falsehoods— I had received this morning two Letters full of anxiety for the effect which the belief of my Masonry would have against me; and one of them intreating me to give a denial of it under my own hand— I told Tracy that if I should deny it, I should not be surprized if they were to produce a forged extract from some imaginary lodge, to counteract my denial— Such are the morals of electioneering. I signed an order for the discharge of Henry Colson, in prison at Alexandria for petty Larceny. Sent Message to Congress N. 5. with the Communications from the Governor of Georgia, concerning their boundary with Florida and Message N. 16. to the Senate with the Creek Indian Treaty.

Mr Lowrie, Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution of that body confirming the renominations I had made for Land-Office Appointments. Dr Watkins came in behalf of Governor Barbour to enquire, if there was a prospect that I would nominate him, for the mission to Great-Britain; and said that Mr Clay had induced him to expect it. I told the Dr that it would be exceedingly agreeable to me to gratify any wish of Governor Barbour, but that I should make no nomination for that mission now; nor probably till the close of the present Session: and that I had induced expectations in another quarter which I could not disappoint. Mr Lincoln came with Mr. M’Coy, a Baptist Missionary among the Indians, with whom I had some conversation upon the subject of that unfortunate race of hunters who are themselves hunted by us like a Partridge upon the Mountains— Mr M’Coy wishes the Government of the United States, to assume the Protection of them, and assign to them a territory where they may remain unmolested— I observed that the Secretary of War had proposed a plan for the Government of them at the last Session of Congress, which had not been acted upon— I observed that our engagements with the Indians, and those among ourselves in relation to their Lands were inconsistent with each other. We had thus contracted with the State of Georgia to extinguish the Indian Title to all the Lands within the State of Georgia, and at the same time stipulated with the Creeks and Cherokees that they should hold their Lands for ever— We have talked of benevolence and humanity, and preached them into civilization; but none of this benevolence is felt where the right of the Indian comes in collision with the interest of the white man— The Cherokees in Georgia have now been making a written Constitution; but this imperium in imperis is impracticable; and in the instances of the New-York Indians removed to Green Bay, and of the Cherokees, removed to the Territory of Arkansas, we have scarcely given them time to build their wigwams before we are called upon by our own people to drive them out again. My own opinion is that the most benevolent course towards them, would be to give them the rights and subject them to the duties of citizens as a part of our own people. But even this the People of the States within which they are situated will not permit— Mr M’Coy left with me a pamphlet written by him on this subject. Mr Niles of Baltimore introduced Mr Schenk, one of the principal manufacturers in the State of New-York. Mr J. C. Scott came to take leave, and to renew his application for an appointment. He is going to-morrow for Virginia. Mr Knight is in a situation similar to that of Satterlee Clark—claiming to be a paymaster in the army, seven years after a successor to him has been appointed. Like him he was sued as a defaulter, and has a verdict of a Jury, and judgment of Court in his favour. He left his memorial and papers with me, and I promised to examine and decide upon his claim— Mr Dupont of Delaware told me he had come to give any information to the Committee on Manufactures that they might desire, but he appeared hurt that they had refused to apply to him for his testimony—he said he was convinced that the object of the majority of the Committee was, to defeat any measure favourable to the manufacturing interest, but to manoeuvre so as to save the reputation of being favourable to it— Mr Tyler introduced Mr Jessup, an Officer of the Customs at New-York, friendly to the Administration, where almost all the others are adverse. Their motives are to be sure of saving their places— Knowing they will not lose them under this Administration; and that they will in the Event of a change, unless they shew their zeal in contributing to it— Governor Barbour brought two Indian Treaties with annexed Documents to be laid before the Senate— I sent Message N. 17 to the Senate with a Report from the Secretary of State, and a translated Ordinance of the king of France of 1826. regulating the trade of the French Colonies— Fourth Drawing-Room this Evening, extremely crowded. I had a conversation with Mr Seymour concerning the appointment of a District Attorney at New-York.

General Van Rensselaer and Mr Dickinson called this morning to speak of the appointment of a District Attorney at New-York. They had heard that I was inclining to nominate General Tallmadge, and came to make representations against him— The only reason that they assigned was that the appointment would produce a bad political effect: Tallmadge as they said having lost the Confidence of all parties. I reminded them that within three years he had been elected by the People, almost unanimously, Lieutenant Governor of the State, and said the turns of popularity in that State were so sudden and complete that it would not be surprizing if within three years he should be with equal unanimity elected Governor— That I knew nothing that he had done to forfeit his popularity—that his standing as a public man was more distinguished than that of either of his competitors— That his qualifications for the Office were unquestioned, and that however irresolute or wavering his general political character may have been, he had not been so to me; as on two important and critical occasions he had been a decisive and most efficient friend to me— These Gentlemen did not reply to my reasoning, but left me quite unconvinced of its force— Mr Livingston introduced a Mr Carleton of Louisiana, who has been some months at the North to recover his health. Mr Sloane, member from Ohio, came to express some apprehensions with regard to the appointment of Mr Webster, as Minister to Great-Britain on account of his political conduct during the late War. I told Mr Sloane that I should make no nomination, certainly till near the close of the present Session of Congress, in the meantime, thanking him for this communication, I should always be glad to see him whenever he might incline to give me his opinions upon any subject of public interest— At two O’Clock Captain Basil Hall, came with Mrs Hall, and their infant daughter, Elizabeth, two years of age— He had requested me last evening to permit him to bring her to see me, to which I had consented— Captain Hall is an Officer in the British Navy who has published an account of the Loo Choo Islands, and a Book of Travels in Chili and Peru— He is now going through the United States with the intention of publishing an Account of his tour— He brought me Letters of Introduction from Mrs Agnes Porter, and from Mr Gallatin; and his Deportment towards me has been marked with flattering civility— The impressions he has left at Boston and at Philadelphia, have not been favourable, and he is equally unsuccessful in making friends here. Mr Clay was here and spoke of the appointment of a District Attorney in New-York. He also told me that about thirty of the manufacturers now here from various parts of the Union called upon him this morning; and that very unexpectedly Mr Niles of Baltimore rose, and in their name pronounced a formal address to him— There was a young man from New-Hampshire who said he had called here at the commencement of the Session of Congress with Mr Bell, the Senator, but whom I did not recollect— He now brought me a recommendation signed by several respectable persons of Daniel M. Christie as District Attorney for New-Hampshire— Mr Blunt was here in the Evening; and said General Van Rensselaer had told him I should probably nominate James Tallmadge as District Attorney at New-York: against which he urged many arguments. Mr Bailey and Mr Hodges, members from Massachusetts afterwards called, and passed the remainder of the Evening with me— Mr Bailey reformed me of the decease of Mrs Webster at New-York, last Monday.

Mr Brent of Louisiana, came to speak in behalf of Simeon Knight an Ex paymaster who claims to be still in that capacity in the service— He had brought me the day before yesterday a memorial and documents in support of this claim— He was in the year 1820 by one order from the War Department sued as a defaulter, and held to Bail at New-Orleans, for 40000 dollars; and by another directed to come to Washington and settle his accounts— He could not obey the last Order, his bail and the Court at New-Orleans having refused him permission to come— But when the suit was finally tried the jury found a verdict in his favour— He then came and reported himself as for Service— But in the meantime by the Law of 15. May 1820 limiting the term of service of Paymasters to four years his commission had expired in May 1821. and another paymaster had been appointed in his place— I told Mr Brent that the Law was positive, and left me no discretion in the case. He said he had told Mr Knight that this was his opinion, but he observed upon the hardship of these proceedings which had ruined Knight, who was one of the best officers that ever had been in the Service— Mr Richardson, a member from Massachusetts came with J. A. Bates, who applies for an appointment as a Purser in the Navy and left with me several papers in support of his claim— Mr Bell, a Senator from New-Hampshire, shewed me a Letter from Pennsylvania, proposing a subscription for the purchase and setting up of a German Newspaper in support of the Administration; and Mr Bell enquired if I should be willing that my Son should contribute to this object— I told him that on a full consideration of the real nature of the transaction I thought it my duty to decline— I said that how far the employment of money to promote the success of the election might be proper in others was not for me to determine— I could only lament the necessity if it existed; but to apply money myself for the promotion of my own election, was I thought incorrect on principle; and I had invariably avoided it— Others I knew, were less scrupulous— It was a widely circulated, and I had no doubt well-founded belief, that De Witt Clinton in 1812. had incurred expenses to promote his election as President of the United States which have crippled him with debt to this hour, and from which he will never be extricated. He paid not only for newspapers; but for agent-emissaries, and even for itinerant preachers— I had been solicited to do the same thing and declined—not from pecuniary considerations, but because I could not approve the thing— Mr Dorsey, member from Maryland came with Mr Brawner, and, Mr Beecher of Ohio with Messrs.Ewing and Goddard, Lawyers from that State attending the Supreme Court. Mr Catlett I barely saw for a moment. Mr Crowninshield came to dissuade me from the nomination of Mr Tallmadge as District Attorney in New-York— General Reid is here with Coll. Ogden, and Alden Bradford as Agents for the Revolutionary Officers, in whose favour there is a bill pending before the Senate. Mr R. G. Amory came to plead in behalf of his Son in Law Captain Freeman, who claims a brevet promotion— Mr Bateman, Senator from New-Jersey and Mr Maxwell, Member of the House from Virginia: of the Committee of enrolled Bills brought me two, which I signed— Mr Rush called with papers of several Subjects before the Department of the Treasury— One related to the Resolution of the House of Representatives calling for the Correspondence, concerning the transfer of the printing and Stationary of the Custom House at Philadelphia— The answer accompanied one short Letter directing the Collector to give the printing and supply of Stationary to J. Binns, as the only Letter on the files of the Department relating to the subject— Another was an application of L. Sawyer, with Rogerson the Collector at Elizabeth City for a marine hospital there— It has much the aspect of a job— A third affair was the seizure of 121 Slaves
at Key-West, which had been taken by an English public vessel, from a Spanish Slave-trader, and run ashore within our jurisdiction— There is a complaint from the Captain of the British vessel, against the Collector at Key West, and a Counter complaint of the Collector against him. I have no doubt it will prove a troublesome affair.— I desired Mr Rush to look over all the papers as soon as possible; that we may determine what shall be done. We had a diplomatic company to dine— Messrs.Arroyo, Bankhead, Nicholas Biddle, Richard Biddle, Daniel Brent, Mr and Mrs Cornewall, Mr Doyle, Captain Basil and Mrs Hall, Chevalier and Madame Huygens, Baron Krudener, Prince Lieven, Count Lillers, Lisboa, Baron and Baronne Maltitz, Count Menou, Mercado, Montoya, Mr and Madame Niederstetter, Obregon, Ochando de la Banda, OuseleyRebello, Rosea, Salmon, Baron Stackelberg, Mr and Madame Tacon, Vaughan, Wallenstein, with five in the family, 35 at table. Abigail S. Adams was unwell, and confined to her chamber. I gave Mrs Hall a Locket for her little girl.

Mr Erwin resides in the State of Tennessee about sixty miles from Nashville. He has been two or three months here, and is upon his return home. He came to take leave, and spoke in terms of high commendation and recommendation of John Williams, and of the late Governor Carroll. Mr Miner, member from Pennsylvania called, and shewed me two Letters that he had received from his District, containing intelligence of hopes and prospects which he thought fair— Mr Blunt came again to take leave. He purposes going to-morrow for New-York, and has given up the expectation of receiving the appointment of District Attorney— Mr Fürst came to tell me that he should return next week to Philadelphia, and to repeat the request of the loan of my father’s Portrait, that he might engrave from it a die for a medal but he also wanted me to give him a written order for one or more of the medals; which I declined; though I told him I would take perhaps half a dozen of them if he should execute the work— He wanted the order as an apology for undertaking it, and said it might otherwise be represented that his motive was to obtain favours from me. I said that imputation appeared still more likely, if I should give him the written order that he desired. That his undertaking was not at my request, as he knew I had rather dissuaded him from it; convinced that in a Country where there is no taste for medals, he could not expect to be paid for his labour on the die. I told him I would pay for and keep the box which he has had made for packing up the Portrait for transportation— Mr Scott came to renew his application for the appointment of Superintendant of the Capitol; an Office which may be created by an Act of Congress now proposed— Mr Scott pleads his father’s great Services, advances of Money and losses, as one of the first Commissioners of the City. Mr Broadmeadow came in much apparent agitation, saying he was informed the act for his relief had passed last Tuesday; and he was apprehensive I had some objection to it, as he had heard it had not received my approbation. I told him that the Act had only yesterday been presented to me; and that I had approved, and signed within half an hour after receiving it, with which assurance he went away much relieved and gratified. Governor Barbour came and spoke of the question between Mr M’Kenney and the Second Comptroller, Mr Cutts, respecting the Settlement of M’Kenney’s Accounts— He observed that he had received yesterday an exceptionable Letter from Mr Cutts, and that rumours were
in circulation, injurious to the Government, which it was necessary to obviate. He said that he had given the directions for the allowances of M’Kenney’s accounts, from an unwillingness to trouble me with them; and an opinion that the charges without vouchers were of such a nature as that vouchers for them could not be obtained— I told him that I would see Mr Cutts, and converse with him on the subject— I had received a Letter from Mr M’Kenney calling for an Order to Mr Cutts and containing more of anger than of explanation. I had thought that an Account might be stated by Mr M’Kenney, which would be satisfactory to Mr Cutts, with vouchers for such charges as usually required them, and leaving those of Presents to the Indians on their customary footing as heretofore. Mr Rush brought a Letter from Dr. Hosack of New-York, and several pamphlets— He recommends the Establishment of three Botanical Gardens— Mr Rush had not yet fully examined the papers relating to the 121 Slaves seized at Key-West. Mr Everett was here in the evening, and told me that there had been in the House of Representatives this day the most disgraceful Scenes he had ever yet witnessed— The debate continues on Chilton’s Resolutions for Retrenchment and Reform— But Chilton himself has now offered another string of Resolutions as a substitute for the first; and confining the attack to the application of the contingent funds of the several departments— My old settled Accounts were again brought into discussion, by Mr Floyd of Virginia, who referred to the erroneous Statement in the Document Vol. 7. N. 120. of May 1822. to exaggerate the amount of sums received by me. Mr Everett told me he intended himself to speak on the question and asked me for information which I gave him— I read to him part of the paper I had drawn up last Spring and left unfinished; and at his request let him take it with him— He also took the volume containing the Document, the error of which I pointed out to him— He will dine with us tomorrow— Mrs Adams and the family spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s.
27. V:30. Sunday— Rainy Morn. Gloomy, dull Noon. Clear Evening.

Heard this Morning at the Unitarian Church Mr Wiswall, from 2. Timothy 1.10. [“]But is now made manifest, by the appearing of our Saviour Jesus Christ, who hath abolished death, and hath brought life and immortality to light through the gospel.” A discourse upon the character of the gospel as a revelation of immortality— Plain and sensible, but without much animation. This doctrine, of a future state of retribution was held as a speculative opinion by the antient heathens, as well as by the Jews— The Christian system was the first that made it a fundamental Article of faith— A blessed futurity as the reward of a life of benevolence includes in the Christian System, the whole hopes and the whole duty of man— Returning home from Church I met Mr R. Cutts, and asked him to call upon me to-morrow Morning. In the afternoon I heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Baker—who preached from the floor, and took for his text the dying words of the Revd. Dr Payson of Portland, an account of whose death he said he had just been reading. They were from Hebrews 12.22.23. “I am going,[”] said Dr Payson, “to mount Sion, and unto the City of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to an innumerable company of Angels,— to the general assembly and Church of the first born, which are written in Heaven; and to God the judge of all, and to the spirits of just man made perfect.” This Sermon was on the same Subject as that of Mr Wiswall in the morning, but it was treated in a different manner— The first was argumentative, to prove the fact—the last was hortatory to secure the enjoyment— What the condition of our future existence will be, or where; or how has not been revealed, and is yet incomprehensible— That it will be reason and revelation concur to shew— Mr Everett dined with us and spent part of the Evening with me— He took some further documents in relation to my old Accounts.
28. V:45. Sun rose 7:3.

Mr Cutts called this morning to speak of the Accounts of Mr T. L. M’Kenney, on his last Indian Missions— While he was here the Secretary of War came in; and we examined the subject all together— Mr Barbour had passed the Accounts of M’Kenney I believe inadvertently, and Cutts declined passing it without vouchers—. The allowance was very reasonable, but much of the expense of presents to Indians and for travelling was of a nature not to admit of regular vouchers— There was a balance standing against M’Kenney upon the Books of one of the Auditors of the Treasury of about 2159. dollars; but he alledges a larger balance upon the books of another Auditor, in his favour, from which it may be set off— I finally proposed that Mr. M’Kenney should state a regular account specifying the charges for presents to the Indians, the charge for travel and the allowance to himself. The question in this case was of some difficulty— The Secretary of War had passed a lumping Account of M’Kenney’s— The Comptroller calls for vouchers. M’Kenney insists that the Secretary has an absolute controul over the appropriation for contingencies, both in the application of the fund, and the Settlement of Accounts— Governor Barbour appears to entertain the same opinion; but I incline to think the Comptroller is in principle correct— Mr Southard called, with a plan of an Island opposite the Navy Yard at Pensacola, covered with live Oak, a part of which is public property; but there are 1600 Acres of it belonging to Mr White the Delegate from Florida, judge Brackenridge, and another person— It is offered for sale upon reasonable terms, and Mr Southard had thought the authority to purchase such Lands had been given by the Act of the last Session, for the gradual improvement of the Navy: but on examining the Act he found it was not— He had partly agreed upon the terms of purchase with judge Brackenridge and Mr White when he discovered his want of authority— He thought it very desirable that the purchase should be made, and I advised him to see Mr Hayne, and Mr Hoffman, the Chairmen of the naval Committees of the two Houses of Congress, and to propose to them to pass an Act giving the necessary authority— Mr Peters came, and introduced his friend Mr Jennings of Philadelphia. Moritz Furst came twice, and again earnestly solicited the loan of my fathers Portrait, for the purpose of engraving from it the die for a medal— I finally consented that he should have it, and took his receipt for it. Had it safely packed in a box, and sent by Antoine to his lodgings. Mr Knight the ex-paymaster came for my decision upon his memorial and claim; and I told him that the Law was imperative: and his commission had expired in four years from its date: that is in May 1821. He then asked, if I could not nominate him to the Senate for a new appointment: and I told him I would consider of it in the event of a vacancy; assuring him that my own disposition towards him was altogether favourable— Tryon was a pedlar of Almanacs, religious tracts, and popular pamphlets, of whom I took Jeremy Taylor’s life of Christ and a couple of Almanacs. Coll. Jones introduced Captain Dearborn of the army; who has some complaint to make about his rank. Jones also left with me a memorial of Lieutenant Walter Smith setting forth a similar grievance— Satterlee Clark also brought me his memorial to which I told him I
should give a written answer and decision— But I said I had attentively read the opinion signed by Mr Oakley and Mr Storrs, and thought they had mistaken a mere defect of evidence, as proof of the non existence of the fact— This was not questionable, and was fully authenticated by the appointment of another paymaster in his place—which as the number of those Offices was limited, could not have happened unless he had been previously displaced— Mr Clay proposed to send copies of the Northeastern boundary Convention to the Governors’ of Massachusetts and of Maine, he spoke also of members of Congress who had conversed with him on the nomination of a District Attorney at New-York; all earnest against Tallmadge— There was an Evening party at Mr Vaughan’s attended by Mary Hellen and John— Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here—
29. V:45. Sun rose 7:2.

Mr Sanford brought me a Letter from Mr Radcliff of New-York to him soliciting the appointment of Charge d’Affaires at Buenos-Ayres, under the expectation that Mr Forbes was on the point of returning home, for cause of ill health. Mr Sanford said that as Mr Radcliff had made this application to him, he had thought himself bound to lay it before me: but he could say nothing in recommendation of the appointment. Mr Radcliff was old and needy, and the office would doubtless be very convenient to him; but he was in several respects altogether unfit for the office— I said there was at least a ready answer to Mr Radcliff; which was that Mr Forbes had not so far as I knew, any intention of resigning his place— I spoke to Mr Sanford of the appointment of District Attorney at New-York and told him I had finally concluded to nominate John Duer— He spoke of him as being perfectly well qualified; but said the nomination was made—leaving me to infer, that if it had not been made he should have thought another choice would have been better— He said he did not know, what the political effect of the appointment might be. The only objection against Duer is old federalism— Mr Buchanan, member of the House from Pennsylvania, introduced his friend Mr Slaymaker, from Lancaster. Mr Gurley, member of the House came to remonstrate against the reappointment of George Davis as Surveyor of Lands South of Tennessee in Louisiana and Mississippi. He said the members from both those States in both Houses of Congress would join in a written remonstrance against him— I said I wished they would also recommend some other person in his place— He said they would probably not be agreed in the person. He himself recommended the Deputy Surveyor, Turner. Mr Tyler came with a Captain Towner who has a claim upon the Government of compensation for having brought home from the Island of Jamaica, a number of Prisoners during the late War with Great Britain— He made the same application three or four years since at the Department of State— He had no sufficient vouchers to substantiate his claim then; and has none now. He alledges that they have been burnt— I told him that his only remedy was by a Petition to Congress— Mr Turner the Collector of Georgetown introduced a Mr Pratt, an old man from Allegany County, Maryland. Mr Biddle the President of the U.S Bank, called with his brother Richard from Pittsburg— There had been a question between them, whether the quotation video meliora proboque; deteriora sequor was from Horace or Ovid— I had pronounced it from Horace, and so had the President of the Bank, and Mr Everett. They had now ascertained that it is in the Metamorphoses Book. 7. lines 20. and 21. a Speech of Medea— I had successively as visitors, Mr Edward Ingersoll of Philadelphia, a Mr David Hoffman of Baltimore; and Major Stark, now of Pembroke New-Hampshire— I had known Major Stark, when I was a student at Haverhill in 1785. I have but an indistinct recollection of having ever seen him since. He came suddenly and unexpectedly into my chamber this morning as I was writing, and said
very abruptly—I suppose you do not remember who I am—yes I do, said I— Well what is my name?— Stark, said I— It was so— Yet forty-three years have seared upon his face lineaments very different from those I had formerly seen upon his— I sent this day to the Senate Message N. 19. with Navy and other Nominations—and Message N. 3. to the House of Representatives; with Correspondence between the Secretary of State and the Brazilian Chargé d’Affaires, Rebello— Message N. 18 with two Indian Treaties had been sent yesterday to the Senate— We had this day company to dine— chiefly manufacturers attending on the Committee of Congress. Theodore Chase, Joshua Clapp, Henry Clay, W. R. Dickinson, E. I. Dupont, David Hoffman, Edward Ingersoll Jennings, Abbott Lawrence, Hezekiah Niles, Richard Peters junr.J. W. Pierce, A. H. Schenk, John Sergeant, Caleb Stark James Wolcott, and W. W. Young—with 5 in the family 21. at table— I wrote little this Evening.
30. IV:45. Wednesday— Sun rose 7:1.

Mr Baker the Pastor of the Presbyterian Church, and Mr Handy the Treasurer called and paid me 300 dollars on Account of the debt due from that Society to me— Judge Duval of the Supreme Court paid a morning visit, not having arrived here when the other judges came on the first day of their Session— Mr Everett called to make enquiry concerning an infamous calumny upon me contained in a note to an electioneering life of General Jackson, published by Isaac Hill, Editor of a Newspaper in New-Hampshire. It is that while in Russia, I attempted to make use of a beautiful girl to seduce the passions of the Emperor Alexander, and sway him to political purposes— This is a new form of Slander—one of the thousand malicious lies which outvenom all the worms of Nile, and are circulated in every part of the Country, in newspapers and pamphlets. I told Mr Everett the incident upon which this tale was raised. That when we went to Russia, a very beautiful girl, a native of Boston named Martha Godfrey went with us, as Chambermaid to my wife and nurse to our Son Charles then a child two years old. Soon after our arrival at St. Petersburg Martha wrote a Letter perhaps to her mother, relating Stories that she had heard there of the Emperor’s amours and gallantries. This Letter having been sent to the Post-Office, was according to the custom there opened, and sent as a curiosity to the Emperor, who was diverted with it and shewed it to the Empress— They both felt a curiosity to see the girls who had written this Letter; and some of the Ladies of the Court who had visited Mrs Adams having seen Charles, with his nurse, had spoken to the Empress of both in such manner as still further to excite her curiosity— The Empress had a Sister then living with her, the Princess Amelia of Baden— She expressed a wish to see Charles, and he was sent one morning to her Apartment in the Palace— Martha his Nurse went with him; and while they were in the Princess’s Apartment, the Emperor and Empress both went there, and passed perhaps ten minutes in talking to the child, and at the same time they had an opportunity of seeing the Nurse, whose Letter had afforded them some amusement— It is from this trivial incident, that this base imputation has been trumped up— There never was any other foundation for it— Martha Godfrey was a girl of irreproachable conduct— She returned to the United States with Mrs Smith; married a very respectable musical instrument maker in Boston, and died there within the last three or four years— Mr Garnsey, member of the House from the western part of the State of New-York came to ask me the question whether I was a Mason
This question absorbs all others upon the electioneering canvas in that part of the Country; and the Slander mongers there disregarding all other lies there only pledge their words, and their oaths that they know me to be a Mason— Garnsey told me that he was himself one; and he gave me to understand that in the event of the formation of a new Territory carved out of Michigan, he would like the Appointment of Governor to it— Governor Duval of Florida came to take leave; being about to return to his Territory. Mr Pearce of Rhode-Island came to introduce Mr Whipple of that State. Mr Bateman a Senator and Mr Tucker a member of the House from New-Jersey, brought a recommendation numerously signed by members of the Legislature of the State, of Gershom Mott, as Collector at Burlington, in the place of Samuel Howell who is about to resign. Samuel Brook of the Treasury came to shew me a Letter from his friend Thomas Shillatoe, whom he had introduced to me last Summer— I signed an order for his discharge from prison of Robert Carter, a mulatto boy, at Alexandria confined for theft, for which he has been whipped.
31. VI— Thursday. Walk round Capitol Square

Dr Hereford, introduced himself to me as a warm political friend from Prince William County, Virginia.— Mr Richardson member from Massachusetts came to enquire concerning the application of J. A. Bates for an appointment as a Purser in the Navy— I told him that I would mention the case to the Secretary of the Navy; but that I believed there was now no vacancy— If any one should happen, Mr Bates’s claim would be considered with those of others— But that he was mistaken in supposing that an acting appointment by Commodore Hull, gave him a right to an appointment by the Government here— The settled principle of the Navy Department was to the contrary— Otherwise the power of appointment assigned by the Constitution to the President with the concurrence of the Senate would in fact be transferred to the Captains of Ships on foreign Service— He said Mr Bates had not been informed of this rule; and by devoting himself to the naval Service had put himself out of the line of other business; and I said that I should in the event of a vacancy do for Mr Bates what I could, consistently with the justice due to others— J. Sergeant member of the House from Philadelphia called and spoke of the debate which has occupied the house for several days, upon resolutions offered by a new member from Kentucky named Chilton. This man after two trials was elected by a majority of forty or fifty votes, upon the strength of declamations at the stump against the wasteful extravagance of the Government, with promises that if elected, he would undertake a reform. Accordingly within a week after taking his Seat, he offered his Resolutions; first declaring the necessity of retrenchment; to save money for paying off the public debt—and secondly proposing reductions of expenditure, not only in the executive Departments, but in the Contingencies of the two Houses of Congress, and in the pay of the members— This movement has disconcerted the party, to which Chilton belongs, by bringing up for discussion general charges of abusive applications of public monies, not only by the Executive, but by the two Houses of Congress; not only by the present, but by past Administrations— Their project had been to point this battery exclusively at this Administration, upon some such charge as 50 dollars paid for an old billiard table— The leaders of the party therefore, who are John Randolph of Roanoke, Samuel D. Ingham of Pennsylvania, and George M’Duffie of South-Carolina, have been struggling, by amendments proposed, to narrow down the discussion, so as to make it bear exclusively upon me and Mr Clay, and while deprecating all general investigations, they have asserted and insinuated, every
slanderous lie with which the newspapers of the last three years have been teeming— This has given rise to recriminations on the part of the friends of the Administration, and to the waste of time, and of public money, more than any retrenchment Committee will ever save— Mr Blake a member of the House from Indiana, introduced a Dr Davis from the Wabash. Mr Southard read me a Letter from Captain Patterson, at Smyrna, giving an Account of the Battle of Navarino on the 21st of October— Mr D. Brent came to enquire concerning a complaint against Hezekiah Huntington U.S. District Attorney in Connecticut— It was referred at the last Session of Congress from the House of Representatives to the President after a Report, unfavourable to Huntington, from the judiciary Committee— Huntington having then been called upon for his defence, by two successive Letters in March and April solicited allowance of time and promised a defence, proving perjury upon his accusers— Since which he has not been heard from. I desired Mr Brent to cause Mr Huntington to be informed that unless his defence should be immediately forwarded, I should proceed to act on his case upon the documents before me— Mr Fendall from the Department of State came and took papers relating to a Petition of John Smith; to be discharged from prison, where he is, in Connecticut under executions at the suit of the United States, to a large amount— These Papers had been left at the Department of State by Mr Phelps, member from Connecticut— The Petition had been referred to the District Attorney Huntington, for a Report which he has not made— I requested Mr Fendall, that he might be called upon for this Report at the same time, that he should be required to forward his defence— Dr Mease of Philadelphia was here. He comes upon the business of his manual for the silk manufacturer. Mr Catlett of Alexandria, came to express his gratification at the nomination to the Senate of John Duer, as District Attorney, for the Southern District of New-York. Ewell brought me a Letter from his mother, again soliciting for him an appointment as a Cadet at West-Point— Mr Clay brought a Note from the British Minister, Mr Vaughan, with several enclosures, relating to the capture of a Spanish Slave-trading vessel named the Guerrero, by a British armed Schooner, from the Bahamas called the nimble, Captain Holland— The Captor and Prize Vessel both grounded on the Florida Reef, within our jurisdiction—the Captor was got off; the prize was wrecked. Some of the Slaves retaken by the prize crews and carried off to Cuba—121 sent by Captain Holland to Key West, and there seized by the Collector W. Pinkney, who also demanded of Captain Holland, payment of duties upon the Cargo saved from the wreck of the prize— Captain Holland refused payment of the duties; demanded the delivery of the Slaves to him, which was denied and he complains of the Collector— Copies of their correspondence have also been transmitted by the Collector, to the Secretary of the Treasury with a request for Instructions— I desired a Cabinet Meeting on the subject, Saturday at one.

Day— differing little from that of the preceding month,. but my average rising hour has been five— Every weekday morning, before breakfast, I have walked round the Capitol Square and an undue proportion of my time has been absorbed, journalizing in this Book; with the abridged Diary for George— It has left me scarcely one hour for miscellaneous reading but it has also left me little leisure to fret my-self because of evil-doers.
